Dr. Qinfang Zhang is currently a full professor at the Yancheng Institute of Technology (Jiangsu, China). He received his PhD degree from the Nanjing University in 2005. His current research focus on the preparation and application of atomic clusters and oxyhalides. From 2005, he has published more than 100 research papers in peer-reviewed journals, such as: Phys. Rev. Lett., Nature Comm., Adv. Mater., Phys. Rev. B, Appl. Surf. Sci., Appl. Phys. Lett. His publications have been cited 3687 times, and his H-Index is 31. He has been leading 14 scientific research projects including the National Defense Science and Technology Innovation Special Zone Project, the National Natural Science Foundation of China, and the Traditional overall water splitting has been regarded as a potential pathway for H2 production, but the intrinsic slow kinetics of the anodic oxygen evolution reaction severely hampers the efficiency of H2 production. Given the challenges in traditional water electrolysis, coupling the kinetically favorable anodic electrooxidation reactions of easily oxidizable substances with the hydrogen evolution reaction in a hybrid water electrolysis (HWE) configuration not only solves the pollutant emission and biomass recycling problems but also maximizes the return on energy profiteering. Various advanced compounds have been engineered through compositional regulation, structural optimization, surface nano-building, and electronic structure modification, yet some issues like tedious preparation and unsatisfactory durability still exist. Considering the gap between research and practical deployment, this review amply addresses the state-of-the-art achievements of synergistic electrocatalysis systems for the co-production of high-purity H2 and valuable products with a low energy consumption and high Faradaic efficiency. An overview of HWE system is presented first accompanied by a discussion on the design and engineering of high reactive/selective/stable electrodes/electrocatalysts for anodic oxidation of organic/biomass substrates. Importantly, the in-depth understanding of possible reaction mechanisms from both experimental and theoretical perspectives is elucidated to promote the efficiency of synergistic electrocatalysis. Subsequently, the recent research breakthroughs in the field of HWE technology are emphatically reviewed, providing a new room for low-voltage H2 generation from waste products and renewable feedstock. Some mechanism explorations, feasibility analyses, and correlation comparisons are highlighted. Finally, we propose the prospects on existing challenges with some opportunities for future research directions to push forward the progress in synergistic electrocatalysis configurations. Graphical Abstract Hybrid water electrolysis technology can generate green H2 at the cathode and value-added chemicals at the anode simultaneously through energy-saving pathway. Thermodynamically more favorable oxidation reactions of organic/biomass substance molecules with a remarkable selectivity greatly offer certain energy-saving advantages. Keywords Anodic electrooxidation reaction Small organic molecule Hybrid water electrolysis Energy-saving H2 production Value-added product Transition metal Synergistic effect Active site Catalytic activity Stability 1 Introduction With the concerns and consideration of elevated global energy demand and serious environmental pollution, the discovery of sustainable energy resources is highly desirable to cut the dependence on consumable fossil fuels (e.g., oil, natural gas, and coal). The progress of state-of-the-art renewable energy systems is key for reaching the sustainable advancement of modern human society [1,2]. Molecular H2 has been extremely considered as one of the most attractive energy carriers for its large energy density and negligible carbon rebirth. Nevertheless, unlike non-renewable energy resources stored on earth, hydrogen energy does not occur naturally and therefore it requires to be manufactured using other resources before being investigated [3–5]. Currently, most of H2 is commonly produced throughout methane steam reforming (accounts for ≍ 96%) with large fossil fuels consumption and low conversion rate under high temperatures (≍ 800 °C). Unfortunately, the resulting H2 gas may be unavoidably contaminated by high amounts of carbon monoxide (CO) and other toxic wastes which can poison the exposed catalytic surfaces and thereby deteriorate the activity during the catalysis process [6]. Moreover, the H2 generation through traditional industrial procedures (e.g., methanol or ethanol reforming) always takes place under high pressure and temperature conditions, which raises energy consumption and demands rigorous infrastructure requirements [7]. To this end, the utilization of an advanced environmentally benign energy-efficient approach for sustainable H2 production at mild conversion is a pivotal step of significant interest from both the environmental and economic viewpoints. Water electrolysis is a well-established energy conversion technology for obtaining pure H2 and remediating the current environmental issues of conventional fossil fuels, where water molecule serves as the solitary starting feedstock and product during the whole cycle of the H2 production. Such a technique can generate clean H2 under ambient conditions with high selectivity, safety, and environmental friendliness [8,9]. Typically, overall water splitting reaction involves a couple of half-catalytic reaction processes namely cathodic HER and the anodic oxygen evolution reaction (OER). In particular, the OER electrocatalytic process is relatively convoluted with a four-electron-transfer step, intrinsically anodic sluggish kinetics, and large theoretical potential (1.23 V vs., reversible hydrogen electrode “RHE”) [10,11]. Hence, the energy adequacy of water electrolyzer stacks is largely restricted by the sluggish kinetics caused by the multiple elementary reaction steps. Simultaneously, the O2 product with little economic value that resulted from the OER process may move to the cathode through the gas crossover effect, creating serious O2/H2 explosive mixtures and consuming extra energy. This also degrades the lifetime of the water electrolyzer membrane due to the generation of highly oxidizing hydrogen peroxide (H2O2), thus hindering the practical application of water electrolysis [11]. Numerous researches have been proposed to develop more efficient electrocatalysts for HER and OER, optimize the composition and micro/nano-engineering, as well as regulate the electronic configuration. Besides, the reaction mechanisms of both HER and OER were also observed through advanced characterizations and theoretical analyses. However, despite these significant endeavors, traditional water splitting faces various obstacles such as explosive O2/H2 mixtures, enlarged thermodynamic potential gaps, worthless anodic products, and reactive oxygen species. Moreover, the high cost hinders the widespread implementation of water splitting technology to form pure H2, achieving a minor portion of the whole H2 generation (≍ 4%) [12]. Given the challenges of traditional water electrolysis, effective approaches have been recently adopted. Among them, the HWE configuration that combines thermodynamically favorable oxidation reaction processes at the anode and HER at the cathode thus comes into the spot as a particularly attractive alternative to maximize H2 production (Fig. 1 ). Hence, substituting the sluggish OER process with thermodynamically more favorable anodic oxidation reactions affords ground-breaking for boosting energy-saving pure H2 production meanwhile enabling additional functionalities such as purifying industrial wastewater and creating high-value-added products [13]. Therefore, exploring alternative electrooxidation reactions at the anode is highly desirable to radically reduce energy depletion and enhance practical use. Recently, several anodic electrooxidation reaction processes of various organic molecules have been introduced in the HWE system to enhance the pure H2 production rate. Most organic electrooxidation reactions display smaller theoretical voltage than that of the OER process (e.g., ammonia oxidation reaction “AmOR, 0.06 V”, hydrazine oxidation reaction “HzOR, –0.33 V”, glucose oxidation reaction “GcOR, 0.05 V”, and urea oxidation reaction “UOR, 0.37”) [12]. In addition, biomass is an abundant carbon-neutral resource with a rich proton amount. In comparison with the thermal conversion routes without carbon storage and capturing, biomass molecules can be applied in chemical synergizing HWE to realize higher system effectiveness, yield inherent zero carbon emissions, and reach added market value in a revolving economy [14]. These substances present broad application prospects to establish competitive coupling technologies of organic electrooxidation reactions at the anode and electroreduction reactions at the cathode like HER, carbon dioxide reduction reaction, and nitrogen reduction reaction [15–18]. Such a pathway not only overrides the safety concerns of reactive oxygen species, O2/H2 mixtures, CO/O2 mixtures, and the explosion of methane but also significantly diminishes energy consumption and elevates economic benefits. Comparatively, electro-catalyzing thermodynamically more propitious anodic oxidation reactions of urea (CH4N2O) [19–32], hydrazine (N2H4) [33–43], methanol (CH3OH) [44–52], ethanol (C2H5OH) [53–58], glycerol [59–63], 2-propanol [64], benzyl alcohol (BA) [65–72], glucose [73,74], and other bio-based compounds to value-added products have been recently received great academic importance [75–79]. Although the electrooxidation of small oxidizable substrates always shows lower theoretical potentials, the apparition of multi-electron transfer steps with major sluggish kinetics and complicated gas evolution paths necessitates the development of highly efficient nano-catalysts. As a matter of fact, the state-of-the-art materials for the OER and HER processes are Ru/Ir-based and Pt-based complexes as both anode and cathode electrocatalysts, respectively, however, the prevalent use of these electrocatalysts is restricted by their rising cost, extreme scarcity, stability dilemma [80]. To increase the practicability of the HWE over conventional OWS for pure H2 production, rational engineering of low-cost and active compounds to improve the kinetics of anodic electrooxidation reactions is a crucial issue. From an economic perspective, substantial advances have been made over the past years in applying earth-abundant transition metal-based electrocatalysts as a substitute for noble metal catalysts with high electrochemical activity for driving the HWE cells to upgrade anodic reductive chemical species and concurrently produce H2. Typical electrocatalyst materials include TMOs, TMHs, TMCs, TMPs, TMNs, and TMBs as well as alloys [81–86]. Notwithstanding considerable advances have been triggered in the catalysis field to highlight the design and development of active compounds in the aspects of basic principles and diverse catalyst types, many previous electrocatalysts suffer from insufficient activity and stability, thus more advanced future studies are required. Additionally, the reports that electrocatalysts perform effectively in an industrially relevant environment have been rarely presented. Other large challenges such as scaled-up manufacturing, structure stability and integrity, and bubble accumulation on exposed surfaces prevent the wide practical application of these electrocatalysts. In recent years, diverse design strategies including hybridization engineering, porosity development, defect engineering, chemical heterointerfacing, heteroatomic engineering, surface functionalization, and electronic configuration modulation have been adopted to further ameliorate the electrocatalytic activity and stability of these catalysts toward the anodic electrooxidation reactions of small molecules [87–98]. Despite many efforts, there is still a broad window to shape it into practical applications and commercialization. The key significance of synergistic electrolysis systems still lacks a more comprehensive and in-depth synopsis of various anodic oxidation reactions and the design of hybrid water electrolyzer-based energy conversion devices. Significant attempts should be localized on constructing highly active transition metal-based alternatives and unveiling the reaction mechanisms for effective reductive chemical degradation. Intriguingly, several studies have recently figured out the effectiveness of synergistic electrolysis by constructing sustainable HWE systems with various oxidizable species in the anode compartment, which would expectedly provide significant opportunities to enrich the co-generation of highly efficient energy-saving H2 gas and value-added chemicals. Such electrocatalytic integrating systems displayed two dignified merits, namely the absence of the O2/H2 mixture and the shortage of the energy input, yielding considerable developments in comparison with the conventional water electrolysis. The anodic electrooxidation reactions of some specific organic substrates, especially urea, alcohol and biomass conversion were reviewed. However, the popularity of studies on such integrating system focuses mainly on the design and synthesis of effective nanostructured anode and cathode electrocatalysts, the reinforcement of the activity/selectivity/durability of electrode/electrocatalyst materials as well as the construction of membranes. For example, Wei and co-workers [99] provided a perspective on multi-functional nano-catalysts derived from layered double hydroxides (LDHs) for high-value upgrading reactions of biomass resources. Wang et al. [100] summarized the latest progress of synthetic strategies to rationally design transition metal-based LDH as electrocatalysts for catalyzing the coupling reactions such as OER, HER, UOR, and biomass derivatives upgrading. Besides, some comprehensive reviews were delivered on non-precious Ni-based complexes for urea oxidation in fuel cells and UOR. Accordingly, the recent breakthroughs of Ni-based and Ni-free materials for H2 generation through overall urea electrolysis systems were summarized [101]. Sayed et al. [102] shed light on employing Ni-based compounds for direct urea fuel cells (DUFCs) and the mechanism of urea electrooxidation on exposed Ni surfaces in alkaline media. Ye et al. [103] provided an overview of the recent progress of DUFCs and anodic urea electrolysis. Additionally, Chen et al. [104] briefly outlined the substitution of anodic oxidation reactions for the sluggish OER focusing on efficient precious metal and precious metal-free electrocatalysts for the anodic oxidation reactions and HER. Sher and co-workers [105] reviewed the recent developments and paradigms of electrolytic H2 production via a more cost-efficient strategy using alcohol electrooxidation reactions. Apart from the above, a brief description was also reported on N2 and CO2 electroreduction integrating with organics oxidation [106]. The authors also reviewed the generation of electricity and/or valuable chemicals through electrocatalytic conversion of organics and elucidated the electrosynthesis directed by the corresponding electrooxidation and electroreduction processes [107]. Based on literature survey, simultaneous production of green H2 and value-added chemicals via synergistic electrolysis-related research lacks a more in-depth and comprehensive description. Other typical synergistic electrolysis of some biomass, amines, and sulfides molecules to H2 and valuable chemicals based on water cycle are very important, but they are rarely stated. Therefore, a more timely review is primary to further disclose the catalytic pathways and significance of different synergistic electrocatalysis systems, which can be employed in electrochemical oxidation-assisted HWE to yield higher efficiency, zero carbon emissions, and added store value. Impressively, the disciplinarian synopsis of the state-of-the-art formulation approaches of cost-efficient bifunctional electrodes/ electrocatalysts to optimize the reaction kinetics and boost electrolyzer cell performance is highly eligible. Keeping this in view, the current review supplies an exquisite elaboration of HWE systems focusing on the anodic electrooxidation reactions of a wide range of hydrogen-rich substances such as alcohol (e.g., methanol, ethanol, benzyl alcohols, glycerol, etc.), urea, hydrazine, biomass derivatives (e.g., 5-hydroxymethylfurfural “HMF” and furfural “FF”), glucose, sulfide, and other carriers to form valuable chemicals at the anode, meanwhile generate pure H2 at the cathode. The systematic understanding of HWE configuration is outlined based on the synergistic electrolysis of the cathodic HER and anodic oxidation reactions and the construction of bifunctional catalytic materials for various operating conditions of hydrogen-rich molecules synergizing HWE. Subsequently, representative research progresses of diverse earth-abundant and noble metal-based bifunctional electrocatalysts for different HWE systems are argued emphasizing efficacious methodologies to reinforce catalytic activity, selectivity, and long-term durability. To heighten the understanding of different anodic reactions, some feasibility analyses, mechanism reconnoitering, and related comparisons are also listed within this section. In the end, the opportunities and challenges for efficient catalyst building, electrolytic cell construction, and potential industrial utilization in the present case of HWE technology are also proposed for future work directions. 2 H2 production through low-temperature water electrolysis approaches Nowadays, the global H2 production surpasses 70 million metric tons per year. This huge amount is used for metal refineries, the oil and gas industry, or transformed into value-added products (e.g., NH3, CH3OH, or specific chemicals). Fig. 2(a) elucidates the global H2 demand divided into end-use partitions. For example, the United States of America consume 80% of produced H2 in the oil and gas sector [108]. As expected, an additional increase in the demand for H2 may be experienced in the future because of its high standard heat of formation (142 MJ kg−1) [109]. Unfortunately, a high storage volume is required for H2 due to its low volumetric density. A huge interest is led by the increasing demand for cleaner energy resources. In this context, the driving forces for the H2 economy across the globe are different, relying on the political landscape, available resources, and opportunities for energy production. Water and biomass are fossil fuel-free sustainable resources for obtaining clean H2. Electrochemical water electrolysis supplies the cleanest strategy for forming H2 due to the carbon-based reaction fuels. Low-temperature electrochemical water electrolyzers can be classified into alkaline electrolyzers and acidic electrolyzers [110]. The schematic illustration in Figs. 2(b)–(d) depicts the major components of an individual cell whereas the real system contains multiple cells (stack). The anode and cathode where the OER and HER take place, respectively are separated by a porous separator to prevent the mixing of O2 and H2 gasses. Finite-gap electrolyzers or conventional water electrolyzers utilize a porous separator in an aqueous KOH solution (5 mol L–1, 30 wt%) as the conduction electrolyte (Fig. 2(b)). The item finite or zero-gap is related to the distance of the separator between the cathode and anode [110]. Alkaline conditions (especially pH > 13) are more favorable for using non-platinum group metal-based electrocatalysts to catalyze the OER and HER processes, while platinum group metal electrocatalysts can work stably in an acidic media. High surface area Raney nickel electrodes are commonly used in traditional/infinite-gap alkaline electrolyzers. The porous separator can reduce the O2/H2 gas crossover, which unfortunately increases the ohmic resistance. This can limit the maximum current densities that can be yielded. The zero-gap water electrolyzers can reduce internal resistance because the established thin polymeric membranes can significantly minimize the H2/O2 crossover. Cation exchange membranes (referred to as proton exchange membranes, Fig. 2(c)) and anion exchange membranes (Fig. 2(d)) are usually utilized for acidic and alkaline zero-gap water electrolyzers, respectively. Therefore, zero-gap water electrolyzers can achieve higher current density than finite-gap electrolyzers. PEMWEs are much more mature than AEMWEs. This is strongly related to the significantly higher stability of proton exchange membranes (typically composed of perfluorosulfonic acid “Nafion”) than anion exchange membranes. However, PEMWEs employing a Nafion separator, are typically performing at 60 °C because the stability of Nafion is limited to 80 °C [109–111]. Recently, bipolar membranes which combine the advantages of the proton exchange membranes (low-cost anode materials in alkaline conditions) and anion exchange membranes (highly durable cathode electrocatalysts in acidic media) have opened new opportunities. In such systems, the proton exchange membrane and anion exchange membrane are in direct contact to construct a bipolar interface. To ensure better performance a water dissociation catalyst layer is added between the two membranes. Another difference between zero-gap and finite alkaline water electrolyzers is that zero-gap water electrolyzers work on a pure water flow or dilute alkali solutions. The usage of pure water prohibits side reactions such as K+ with CO2 to create carbonate species in OH– environments, but demands an anion-exchange ionomer, an OH– conductive polymer to be present in the catalyst layer. However, the complete elimination of CO2 is challenging even with pure water or low KOH concentrations because the CO2 in the air can easily dissolve in water. Zero-gap systems-based PEMWEs have attracted much attention because the construction of AEMWEs is strongly associated with the availability of stable AEMs at elevated temperatures. The significant role of membranes is to deliver pure H2 directly from the cell [109–111]. Table 1 Comparison of low-temperature water electrolyzer systems. Water electrolysis Advantage Disadvantage Traditional/ infinite gap alkaline electrolyzers 1) low capital costs 2) low-cost electrocatalysts are frequently used in both anode and cathode 3) relatively stable 4) large scale 5) mature technology 6) low-cost transition metals and compounds are employed as anodes 1) O2/H2 gas crossover 2) low current densities 3) low operational pressure 4) low efficiency and low dynamics 5) corrosive electrolyte AEMWEs 1) combination of traditional alkaline water electrolyzer systems and PEMWEs 2) transition metals and compounds are typically used as the anode electrocatalysts 1) low OH– conductivity 2) limited durability 3) lab-scale technology 4) low efficiency 5) high cost of AEMs PEMWEs 1) compact design 2) rapid start-up and response 3) offering a high purity H2 4) large current densities 5) high efficiency 6) commercialized technology 1) high costs of noble metal electrocatalysts and PEMs 2) acidic corrosion environment 3) limited durability Regardless of the enhancement of water electrolysis via the aforementioned strategies, various technical issues including, large energy barriers, possible H2/O2 crossover, sluggish kinetics of the OER process, incompatible kinetics and pH-dependent overpotential for the OER and HER, as well as limited mass transfer of reactants still occur. New emerging approaches such as acid/alkaline asymmetric electrolyte electrolysis, overall water electrolysis, and HWE may advance the large deployment of water electrolysis systems and address the above challenges. In particular, the HWE approach can overcome the limitation of the OER and minimize the energy loss of water electrolysis by replacing the OER with an alternative thermodynamically more favorable electrooxidation reaction (Fig. 3 ). 2.1 Advantages and disadvantages of energy-saving H2 production through co-generative configurations HWE technique combined with the more readily oxidizable organic/biomass molecule possesses several merits (Fig. 4 ): (1) the onset potential of organic/biomass molecule electrooxidation reaction is less than that of the OER, hence hybrid electrolyzers can reach large current densities with smaller voltage input. The more favorable electrooxidation thermodynamics of chosen organic/biomass substance molecules promote energy conversion efficiency. (2) The anode can generate value-added products, contributing to the ultimate payback of energy investment, (3) liquid organic compounds can be created instead of O2 gas, thus eliminating the occurrence of H2/O2 mixture. (4) The individual compartment electrolysis cell without any membranes or diaphragms can be possibly established if the oxidative products or substrate molecules will not be easily reduced or not compete with the HER. This will save the cost of membranes. To approach these advantages, optimal feedstock chemical substance should satisfy the following criteria: (1) substrates should be abundant, comparatively cheap, and non-polluting [81], (2) high solubility in water at the ambient conditions, (3) formation of value-added non-gaseous oxidative products at the anode, enabling high-efficiency power-to-fuel/chemical conversion [81,112], (4) more less positive oxidation voltage compared to the onset potential of OER, and (5) insignificant competition with the HER process at the cathode. 3 Overview of HWE Generally, HWE is substantially similar to that of conventional OWS at the cathode compartment. HWE system can simultaneously liberate pure molecular H2 and other valuable chemicals with theoretically superior energy efficiency than classical water electrolysis [113–115]. HER with a two-electron transfer step dominates at the cathode side of HWE as described by Eqs. (1) and (2). On the counter side of the cathode, anodic electrooxidation reactions of organic substrates are engaged in the HWE configuration, unlike the commonplace OER process in conventional water electrolysis. The four-electron OER with inveterate sluggish kinetics remains a big hurdle to manipulate the performance of conventional water electrolysis. (1) In alkaline conditions: 2e– + H2O → 2OH– + H2 (2) In acidic conditions: 2e– + 2H+ → H2 When coupling favorable organic oxidation reactions at the anode and HER at the cathode, the HWE system provides extra benefits of decreasing the electricity consumption for sustainable H2 generation, averting the formation of useless O2, yielding chemical purification and biomass valorization, and synchronously inducing the production of economically viable species at the anode with smaller cell potentials, thus enhancing the energy conversion efficiency for pure H2 generation [116–119]. H2 is the only product in classical water electrolysis. On the other hand, value-added species are yielded in HWE through the electrooxidation of biomass or organic-derived substrates meanwhile pure H2 can be also released. For instance, the selective electrooxidation reaction of alcohols yields ketone, carboxylate, and even corresponding ester at the anode while evolving pure H2 at the cathode with no serious explosion of the H2/O2 mixture. Moreover, 2,5-furandicarboxylic acid (FDCA), furoic acid (FA), maleic acid, and gluconate can be produced from the electrooxidation reactions of biomass oxidation. Furthermore, the electrochemical oxidation of amines can create nitriles, amine oxides, amides, and azo complexes for various agrochemical and pharmaceutical uses. Therefore, the potential generation of specific value-added chemicals is another stringent criterion for appreciating various electrooxidation reactions. Simultaneously, directing the reaction path for more beneficial species is an important sight for chemicals with complicated competing electrooxidation processes. In addition, a high-purity product design is needed to lower the investment in separation and refinement. The insertion of favorably oxidizable organic molecules into electrolytes at the anode compartment with the cathodic HER decreases the working catalysis potential, making the process extremely attractive. It should be noticed that integrating both anodic electrooxidation reactions and cathodic HER would bring tussle since the two established half-reaction processes may need different electrolysis conditions (e.g., solvents, electrolyte solutions, reaction rates) [9]. Hence, it is requisite to nominate proper electrooxidation reactions based on electrochemical precepts of electro-coupled catalytic processes. Reaction parameters of assembled HWE systems should be strictly adjusted. Optimized chemical feedstock concentration, pH values of electrolyte solution, cell voltage, and electrolyte flow should be realized for an exemplary operating environment. It is worth noting that the reaction conditions should be customized not only in various HWE configurations but also in different weather conditions and industrial requirements. Of equal interest, exploring cost-effective electrocatalytic complexes is pivotal to accelerate catalytic reactions. Several compounds have been developed and applied in conventional water electrolysis. Different electrocatalytic activities, chemical stabilities, and other properties can be reached by employing various active components, structures, compositions, and morphologies. The requirement of HER electrodes/electrocatalysts in HWE is essentially similar to that in traditional water catalysis with identical kinetic and thermodynamic parameters. However, in view of anodic oxidation reactions in HWE, different assessing criteria on activity, stability, and selectivity should be taken into account when preparing especially proper and efficient electrodes/electrocatalysts. 3.1 Anodic electrooxidation reactions Anodic electrooxidation reactions can replace the multi-electron OER process and fulfil all the requirements for substitutional oxidation half-reactions. The anodic electrooxidation reaction of readily oxidizable substrate molecules can be classified into three directions [12]: (1) substrate-based value-added group (e.g. glucose, biomass-derived substrates, methanol, glycerol, ethanol, EG, and BA) which generate H2 with narrow voltages, meanwhile form valorised products, (2) substrate-sacrificing group (e.g. hydrazine and ammonia), in which sacrificial reactant molecules are oxidized into valueless products at the anode and release at H2 the cathode, and (3) substrate-based pollutant degradation group (e.g. urea, sulfides, and organic dyes) in which the substrates are pollutants (Fig. 3). The anodic electrooxidation of various organic compounds and other chemical species is indeed a very attractive technology for replacing the OER and decomposing organic/biomass molecules. Products harvested from the anodic electrooxidation of substrate-based value-added types involve the building units for pharmaceutical and polymer manufacturing. However, the organic/biomass species react on the electrode surface, forming oxidants for the anodic oxidation reaction processes. In general, the feasibility of an electrochemical oxidation process of organic substrate depends on the occurrence of chemically or physically adsorbed hydroxyl radicals, electrode material, and competition with the OER [117–120]. The selective electrooxidation of organic molecules includes the generation of multiple reaction intermediates following different reaction mechanisms [117]. These processes may occur with no loss in the anode activity, except under higher voltages. Moreover, the nature of electrode material strongly impacts both the efficiency and selectivity of these reactions. Based on these findings, the electrochemical oxidation of organic substrate in aqueous media includes anodic oxygen transfer from water through hydroxyl radicals (OH*) caused by water decomposition. The oxidation of water molecules (Eq. (3)) creates adsorbed hydroxyl radicals (OH*) in which the chemical and electrochemical activities of OH* depend strongly on the anode material. With an effective electrode material, the robust interactions between the electrode material (M) and OH* guide the formation of the so-called higher oxide MO (Eq. (4)). This may be ascribed to the presence of higher-valence M(OH*) species for the electrode material [112,117]. (3) H2O + M → e– + H+ + M(OH*) (4) M(OH*) → e– + H+ + MO Generally, the anodic electrooxidation reaction-based organic substrate molecule involves the dehydrogenation of one hydrogen linked to the carbon in the organic substrate and one hydrogen from the hydroxyl group as a master step. In Eq. (5), R reflects a fraction of an organic substrate without heteroatomic species, which can be fully transformed into CO2 with the assistance of one oxygen atom. The MO/M redox couple of the anode serves as a mediator during the electrooxidation reaction of organic molecules. The reaction competes with the side reaction of the OER process directed by the chemical decomposition of higher oxides (Eq. (6)). Therefore, the anodic oxidative reaction through the surface redox couple MO/M may be more selective. (5) R + MO → R(O) + M (6) MO → 1/2O2 + M The anodic oxidation of heteroatom-free organic substrate is mediated by hydroxyl radicals and causes fully oxidized products such as CO2 (Eq. (7)). Such a reaction competes with the side reaction of OH* to oxygen by forming hydrogen peroxide as an intermediate without any collaboration of the anode surface (Eq. (8)). Hence, highly active electrodes/electrocatalysts with numerous electrocatalytic sites can efficiently optimize the adsorption/desorption of reaction intermediates and/or products from aqueous medium. (7) R + M(OH*) → nH2O + mCO2 + M + e– + H+ (8) M(OH*) → e– + H+ + M + 1/2O2 The performance of H2 generation via the HWE technology can be evaluated using important electrolysis parameters (e.g., current density, overpotential, selectivity, stability, yield, and Faraday efficiency (FE)). The selectivity, FE, and yield can be calculated as follows (Eqs. (9)–(11)) [121–123]: (9) Selectivity (%) = n(product yield)/n(initial consumed) ×100% (10) FE (%) = mzF/Q × 100% (11) Yield (%) = n(product yield)/n(initial small molecule) × 100% where m, z, F, and Q denote the molarity of harvested chemical, number of electrons, Faraday constant (96485 C mol– 1), and total charges along the catalyst, respectively. In water electrolysis, FE calculates the ratio of the analyzed amount of H2 or O2 produced to the theoretically measured amount, assuming that all charges are fully utilized to generate H2 or O2. In a practical assessment, the quantity of as-formed H2 or O2 in an electrochemical process is measured by gas chromatography (GC) or the water-gas displacement method. The GCD measurements are performed based on the overall volume of harvested H2 and the H2 calibration plot should be accurately adjusted. In the case of water-gas displacement technique, actual atmospheric pressure should be evaluated because of possible shift from the standard atmospheric in the central area. The charge transported during a certain period can be detected by the electrochemical workstation [124]. The FE loss experienced in water electrolysis is largely related to electrons and ions participating in side reactions. While ideal electrocatalysts should reveal 100% FE. Advanced analysis tools such as high-performance liquid chromatography (HPLC), Fourier-transform infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR), and nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) are usually applied to observe the anodic products. While drainage strategy is commonly employed to probe the H2 collection at the cathode side. HWE system must be conducted on the same solution environment to reduce the potential, which is extremely challenging with the engagement of non-precious metal catalysts owing to poor electrochemical stability or deteriorated activity in strong electrolytes. Hybrid alkaline electrolyzers, where a typical KOH solution is the common electrolyte and Ni-based transition metal electrocatalysts are frequently used as the working electrodes usually reveal large current densities and long lifetime ascribed to the tunable activity and stability of Ni-based catalysts. The major drawback of the alkaline HWE system is the limited active electrode area caused by the assemblage of gaseous bubbles on an exposed electrode surface, which is hardly prohibited in liquid electrolyte solutions. In contrast, the usage of noble metal Pt as the cathode catalyst and Ru or Ir-based oxide as the anode catalyst in acidic media with enhanced corrosion resistances will markedly raise the overall cost and consequently limit the widespread practical application [12,122]. Other inexpensive transition-metal-based compounds suffer very poor anti-acid corrosion properties. Thus, alkaline and neutral HWE configurations may show obvious advantages versus acidic HWE systems for low-cost and large-scale H2 production due to the high solubility of non-noble metal compounds in substantially acidic environments. Till now, a wide range of bifunctional electrocatalysts for HWE systems have been presented. To yield efficient and stable anodic electrooxidation reactions of readily oxidizable organic/biomass molecules, the design principles of electrodes/electrocatalysts must be optimized to meet the following key criteria. (1) Optimize the reaction thermodynamics and adsorption energy of reactants and reactions intermediates or products on exposed catalytic surfaces, (2) promote the kinetics and attain synergistic electrocatalysis of multiple active sites, (3) induce the formation of reactive intermediates. 3.2 Synergistic electrocatalysis of anodic oxidation reactions integrated with cathodic HER Developing and understanding electrocatalysts requires accurate evaluation of corresponding activity and thereby some common matrices should be justified. The synergistic electrochemical catalysis configuration displays better electrocatalytic kinetics in alkaline electrolytes. Therefore, we investigated the OWS in alkaline conditions as an onset point to observe the key effects of the OWS process on the co-electrolysis system. It is well-known that both HER and OER half reactions proceed via multi-electron processes and involve multi-step reaction paths with Had, OHad, and Oad intermediates. The electrocatalytic HER process involves the adsorption/decomposition of water molecules in alkaline solutions to yield Had and OH–, adsorption/desorption of OH–, and the generation of intermediates to release molecular H2 with low external applied potential. The Volmer reaction describes the interaction between a proton and an electron to create an adsorbed hydrogen (H*) atom on the catalytic active sites (Eq. (12)). Subsequently, the generation of hydrogen may take place via the Tafel reaction or the Heyrovsky reaction, or both. In the Tafel step, the combination of two neighboring H* on the electrode surface can direct the H2 release (Eq. (13)). Whereas, in the Heyrovsky step, the H* atom combines with the water molecules to produce H2 (Eq. (14)) [122,123]. Upon the assumption that the chemical combination reaction between the H* and catalyst surface is weak, the Volmer step will control the overall HER rate. In contrast, very robust binding interaction means that the Heyrovsky/Tafel reaction is the rate-determining step. The HER rate-determining step is always calculated from the Tafel slope (b), which elucidates the mechanism of the HER process. Slope values equal to 30, 40, and 120 mV dec−1 designate the Tafel, Heyrovsky, and Volmer reaction limitations, respectively. (12) Volmer step: e– + H2O → OH– + Had (13) Tafel step: 2Had → H2 (14) Heyrovsky step: e– + H2O + Had → OH– + H2 It is a primary half-reaction in rechargeable metal-air batteries, however, it is an inherently more complex catalytic process since it demands a four-electron transfer process through multi-step reactions with a single-electron transfer in each step. Consequently, the energy accumulation at each step increases the sluggish kinetics of the OER process, thus a large overpotential is necessary to overcome the energy barrier. This implies inferior energy conversion efficiency, limited lifetime, and low stability [122,123]. The OER process produces molecular O2 via a complex electron transfer process. In alkaline electrolytes, the adsorption/oxidation of OH– ions on catalytic active sites forms a water molecule and an oxygen molecule (Eqs. (15)–(17)). The OER process in alkaline conditions can generally occur via the following pathway: (15) OH– → e– + OHad (16) OH– + OHad + → e– + H2O + Oad (17) 2Oad → O2 Generating O2 via the Oad intermediate may include two paths: the integration of two OOad to release O2 and the other path initially creates OOH (Eqs. (18) and (19)) [122]. (18) OH– + Oad → e– + OOHad (19) OH– + OOHad → H2O + e– + O2 The conventional OWS process requires a larger voltage than the thermodynamic one. Such a higher operational voltage is mostly investigated to beat the intrinsic activation barriers at the anodic and cathodic electrodes due to the multi-step reactions of both HER and OER processes. This undoubtedly leads to an enormous energy barrier for H2 generation employing OWS. To ameliorate this obstacle, anodic electrooxidation reaction-cathodic HER synergistic systems with the overall utilization of water-derived Oads species can boost the reaction kinetics. Under this scenario, the electrochemical pairing of valuable species and H2 co-production can be impressively conducted comprising more favorably selective electrooxidation reactions. Such electrocatalytic integrating systems directly use the readily accessible Oads and Hads resulting from water degradation before the occurrence of HER and OER, hence favoring energy consumption reduction [12,124]. By regulating the water catalysis process, the binding between Oads and Hads species and driving catalyst of electro-coupled anodic oxidation reaction-cathodic HER configuration can be effectively modulated, which is advantageous for the profound conception of the genuine reactive sites of synergistic HWE and corresponding catalytic pathways. In this regard, various research works demonstrated that the Oads or Hads species induced by decomposed water molecules could significantly promote the anodic oxidation reaction-cathodic HER synergistic electrolysis system. For example, Zhang et al. [125] confirmed the effect of OH* on catalyst reconstruction in which the in-situ Raman spectroscopy analysis proved the transient conversion of the NiO phase into nickel oxyhydroxide (NiOOH) during an anodic electrooxidation reaction of tetrahydroisoquinoline. Recently, the reaction mechanism of oxidative lignin upgrading on Mn-doped CoOOH catalyst was revealed through the density functional theory (DFT) calculations and isotope labeling tests [126]. Obtained outcomes indicated that the resulting OH* could activate the chemical bonds by introducing the reactants of intermediates in the reaction. Additionally, Wang et al. [127], claimed that the adsorbed OOH* on exposed surfaces of NC@CuCo2N x catalyst facilitated the formation of Cu-CoOOH, which acted as the actual active catalytic sites for BA electrooxidation. The robust conjunction between the CoN and CuN components stabilized the adsorption energy of active OOH* species and improved the electronic structures, thus strengthening the activity and selectivity. The reaction mechanisms of anodic electrooxidation reaction-cathodic HER synergistic electrocatalysis mainly depend on ex-situ characterization tools and theoretical calculation analyses. Simulation approaches can offer information on the reaction pathways and adsorption/desorption of Oads and Hads species. Incorporating various ex-situ characterization tactics such as 1H-nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectroscopy, isotope labeling, and mass spectrometry jointly demonstrate that the Oads and Hads come from water. Electron spin resonance (ESR) spectroscopy may identify the effective oxygen radicals in the anodic electrooxidation reaction. However, the trapping of intermediates and dynamic reconstruction are still difficult to observe in real-time, bringing difficulties in understanding the exact catalytic mechanism. With the fast growth and exploitation of advanced characterization tools, various in-situ characterization instruments have been used in sustainable energy storage and catalysis systems. For example, to track the catalytic reaction pathways, structural and compositional variations post the interaction between exposed active sites of the electrode/electrocatalyst and reactants during the catalytic process, in-situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), in-situ X-ray diffraction (XRD), in-situ X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS), in-situ Raman spectroscopy, in-situ infrared (IR) spectroscopy, in-situ differential electrochemical mass spectrometry (DEMS), and in-situ ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) light spectroscopy are usually used. In-situ scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and in-situ transmission electron microscopy (TEM) observations can be performed to explore the micromorphologies of applied electrodes/electrocatalysts. Hence, the internal catalytic mechanism of electrodes/electrocatalysts in the HWE synergistic system may be deeply understood by investigating in-situ or operational characterization devices. 3.3 Thermodynamic equilibrium potential HWE systems with high electronic utilization rates and greatly improved energy efficiency are filled with research endeavors and application momentousness. The oxidation reaction processes generally proceed via multi-electron transfer steps. Thus, the kinetics of both anodic/cathodic reactions should be optimized to direct the synergistic electrolysis. Meanwhile, continuous regulation of catalytic systems to approach renewability and sustainability via the water catalysis cycle represents a key to efficient H2 evolution and selective production of value-added species. The sluggish kinetics of the OER process on numerous active electrocatalysts were excessively pointed out [109,122]. However, the substantial nature of oxygen with a large thermodynamic equilibrium potential increases the driving voltage of conventional OWS. Hence, incorporating easily oxidizable organic/biomass substrate molecules with smaller oxidation potentials into the water splitting system by coupling the cathodic HER with thermodynamically favorable anodic oxidation reactions can reduce the total energy input. For example, Ru nanoparticles (NPs) anchored on nitrogen (N)-doped mesoporous carbon (Ru/MPNC) with strongly coupled Ru-N-conductive C matrix interaction were rationally designed and applied as a bifunctional electrocatalyst for HzOR-directed HWE system with an equilibrium voltage of 0.33 V vs. RHE [128]. The as-fabricated Ru/MPNC(+,–) two-electrode HWE electrolyzer reached a high current density of 50 mA cm−2 at an ultra-low cell potential of 0.149 V, which was 1.051 V lower than that of conventional OWS. In addition, a high hydrogen evolution rate (0.893 mmol L−1 h−1) could be yielded through a direct hydrazine-H2O2 fuel cell. The multi-component NiS@Ni3 S2/NiMoO4 nanocomposite with plenteous heterointerfaces was evaluated for catalyzing UOR in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH solution [129]. The electron environment was optimized, creating a nucleophilic oxygen zone and electrophilic Mo region to further boost the anodic decomposition of urea molecules. The dual-electrode assembly-based HWE system could approach 10 mA cm−2 at a cell potential of 1.9 V (190 mV lower than the OWS cell potential). Consequently, the thermodynamic equilibrium voltage of the proposed chemical feedstock is a decisive parameter in designing the HWE configuration. Fig. 5 illustrates the thermodynamic equilibrium potentials of several organic/biomass substrate molecules synergizing HWE systems. It can be observed that the urea, HMF, methanol, and BA as well as glycerol exhibit smaller oxidation potentials compared with the OWS. Moreover, hydrazine possesses ultra-low thermodynamic oxidation potentials, manifesting tremendous advantages in reducing the energy input and operating voltage. The listed thermodynamic equilibrium potentials in Fig. 5 are probably due to complete oxidation processes. Typically, the electrochemical oxidation of methanol molecules in an alkaline environment produces CO3–, whereas CO2 is formed in acidic media. 3.4 Economic and environmental considerations Noticeably, the main objective of this part is to monitor the potential viability of various synergistic electrolysis systems for near future development based on prominent values, not to report their techno-economic formulation. This may help the scientific association to define and screen the most pertinent series of procedures that supply significance in a decarbonized future. Although HWE configurations bring tremendous benefits, the possible increase in capital and operational costs such as complex chemical methods for purifying and separating final liquid products should be considered at a later step [61]. Besides, the anodic electrooxidation reactions may intensify the complexity of the reactor cell because of specific requirements for various organic/biomass substrate molecules and related final products. Therefore, more focus from both the economic and theoretical parties is necessary to establish high-performance HWE technology. The cost of feedstock plays a decisive role in evaluating the economic viability of the HWE configuration. Some of the feedstock substances for anodic electrooxidation reactions are expensive resources, hence the cost of raw material must be adjusted in the choice of proper chemicals or specific chemicals from diverse sources [41–79]. Unusually, the cost of feedstock chemicals may be negative. In the case of urea synergizing HWE, the feedstock substance, urea is extensively distributed in wastewater. In view of toxic products of naturally decomposed ammonia and nitrate, the exhaustion of urea is economic, thus ensuring a negative cost on feedstock chemicals. Side-by-side, the cost of raw material for driving seawater electrolysis can also be considered negative because the cost of seawater purification/desalination or pure water transportation will be eliminated. The anodic electrooxidation of bio-derived chemicals can create products of high economic importance, which would afford an additional income, implying a much more cost-competitive option. Correspondingly, the anodic electrooxidation reactions of glycerol molecules under alkaline conditions allow the formation of several products (e.g., glycolate, oxalate, hydroxypyruvic acid, formate, carbonate, and potassium glycerate) together with the H2 gas at different selectivity. Some of the co-products are fine chemicals in the worldwide marketplace and the need for these outcomes is expected to elevate due to the advancement in biopolymer and pharmaceutical applications [130]. Additionally, glucaric acid could be generated via electrochemical oxidation reactions of glucose on a NiFeO x electrode [92]. Importantly, the future desire for green H2 is expected to grow considerably beyond that of the co-products. This may push forward the overall deployment potential of HWE technology. The selectivity for various co-products would directly influence the global warming potential and price of H2. Decreasing the synthesis costs of efficient electrodes/electrocatalysts is also crucial to amplify the possibility of practical application. In this regard, the cost related to raw materials, preparation methodologies, and environmental impacts should be optimized. Electrodes/electrocatalysts are primarily chosen based on their capability to direct redox reactions with a small energy loss. Electro-generation via selective anodic electrooxidation reactions takes place via multiple steps such as adsorption of reactant molecules, bonding interactions, electron transfer kinetics, oxidation into intermediates and final products. The synergistic electrolysis reactions in HWE systems and corresponding chemical transformation by the simultaneous transfer of numerous electrons and protons require an optimized charge transportation rate. Thus, investigating bifunctional nano-electrodes/nano-catalysts is necessary to maximize the transformation efficiency. The prudent integration of electrochemical, spectroscopic, and chromatographic techniques gives more insights into the conversion rate of reactants, intermediates, and product allocation at both quantitative and qualitative levels. More specifically, the anodic oxidation processes require delicate control of reaction kinetics and steps which are strongly associated with the compositional, structural, and electronic features of active compounds. The appraisal parameters including, overpotential, onset potential, catalytic current density, stability, and selectivity are similar to traditional electrocatalysis but with distinguished characteristics for organic molecule transformation. Hence, the overall electrocatalytic behavior of a catalyst can be identified based on the number of active sites and selectivity of every single site. The electrooxidation processes form numerous value-added species as co-products with certain environmental impacts. The overall universal calefactory of these processes relies on the upstream emissions related to the nature of raw materials and the source of electricity. In fact, the electrooxidation of biomass or organic substrates in HWE systems may offer more economic opportunities compared to OWS, albeit with a higher universal calefactory impact, however, it possesses a smaller universal calefactory impact compared to conventional reforming of steam methane and may play a role in the transition to net-zero emissions. Minimizing the CO2 footprint of feedstock certifies a frivolous universal calefactory effect. Consequently, there is a trade-off between the environmental impact and economic viability of these processes. Currently, there is an intense potential to decrease the CO2 footprint due to heat and electricity in carbon-neutral societies. Nonetheless, upcoming research attempts in this field must be pursued to maximize the selectivity toward green H2 generation. Upon extended run, the organized environment may simplify the discovery of much cleaner substances, which would modulate both the environmental behavior and economics of these processes. Detailed layouts require to be carefully explored for the running of these processes commercially to recognize the overall energy requirements, costs, and eventual global warming potential. Future research should also highlight the total impact of plant construction, working styles, and decommissioning on global warming potential. According to the above discussion, the development of high-efficiency HWE systems faces three major obstacles: (1) rational engineering of catalytically active complexes to constrain the activation energy for H2 production at the cathode side and the formation of valuable species at the anode. This will control the energy consumption for the selectivity of valuable chemicals and H2 production [21]. (2) Deep recognition of the major electrocatalytic process and interfacial steps for various substrates, which may offer more guidance toward the precise control of the whole reaction process and strengthen the selectivity for desired products. (3) Scaling up the HWE technology for effective practical usage. Therefore, in the following section, we will focus on the rational construction of bifunctional nano-electrodes/nano-catalysts based on three prime aspects (e.g., morphological and surface engineering, electronic structure regulation, and interface construction). 4 Rational engineering of bifunctional nano-electrodes/nano-catalysts for driving HWE systems To accelerate the deployment of HWE technology and the co-generation of high-value products with clean H2, advanced electroactive nanomaterials with high performance are extensively demanded [131–135]. It is worth mentioning that electrochemical oxidation reactions are surface-sensitive processes, which can be largely influenced by the properties and chemical state of employed electrocatalysts. Scientists herein have been encouraged to manufacture low-cost, highly effective, and chemically stable nano-compounds as applicable bifunctional electrodes/electrocatalysts. The catalytic active sites would be able to be adequately accessed by the electrolyte and reactants. Consequently, methodologies have been implemented to gain the proper exposed surface with improved characteristics by manipulating the chemical structure, surface morphology and composition [131–139]. High-performance and chemically stable nanomaterials are strongly indispensable to drive the anodic electrooxidation reactions of organic/biomass substrates with intrinsically tunable kinetics. Stability is a significant factor in realizing the potential practical applications of electrodes/electrocatalysts. Currently, the stability of an electrode/electrocatalyst is evaluated via several methods: accelerated degradation test based on repetitive CV technique (several hundreds or thousands of cycles) under higher sweep rates. The LSV spectrum is recorded to calculate the overpotential shift at a certain current density (commonly 10 mA cm−2) [124]. A very little shift in overpotential implies a high stability. Along with this, stability can be tested for a few or several hours at a constant polarization by using the chronoamperometry technique (i-t response at a fixed potential) or chronopotentiometry method (V-t response at a fixed current density). Earth-abundant transition metal-based nanomaterials usually exhibit good stability in alkaline electrolyte solutions. While, they suffer severe degradation and dissolution in acidic solutions, revealing obvious activity decays with the decrease of pH. This is appreciably predicted from a commercial prospect. In general, the drop-casted electrodes are less durable than the self-supporting ones. Dignified efforts have been awarded to enhance the stability of electrochemically active nano-compounds by enhancing their structural/compositional features and constructing protective layers. However, several drawbacks related to mass transport limitations are still present and smart stability-optimizing approaches are expected. Besides, the long-term durability under industrial-level current densities in special reaction conditions is still questionable. The durability of electrodes/electrocatalysts in HWE systems should be carefully considered due to the complicated environment in synergistic electrocatalysis compared with traditional water catalysis [44–79]. The electroactive site maintaining, individual structure, and engineered morphology should be given a high priority. The electrode surface blockage, activity degradation, competing reactions, solid impurities and microbial contaminations must be eliminated. An electrode/electrocatalyst is recognized to be durable with either an insignificant increase in overpotential during chronopotentiometry experiments or stable current density during chronoamperometry tests under continuous electrolysis operation. Furthermore, in-situ or ex-situ characterization apparatuses such as SEM, TEM, XRD, XPS, and inductively coupled plasma analysis can be coupled to detect the compositional, structural, and architectural stability. The engineering strategies for enhancing the intrinsic electrochemical activity of components can be understood via common aspects: multi-component synergistic effect, compositional/structural effect, interface effect, and electronic/ensemble effect [140–142]. Note that the electrode/electrocatalyst materials might be fabricated by combining dual collaborative features to maximize the advantages. The amount of catalytic active sites can significantly influence the complex multi-electron electrooxidation process. Hence, engineering three-dimensional (3D) architectures may efficiently expose abundant active sites. Meanwhile, the synergism between multiple active centers boosts the reaction kinetics. Adjusting the electronic configurations and d-band center as well as optimizing the charge redistribution of nano-structured components by heteroatomic insertion, vacancy engineering, and heterojunction construction will optimize the adsorption/desorption energy of reactants, reaction intermediates, and final products. Thus, modifying the thermodynamic processes of anodic oxidation reactions. The capability to reinforce mass penetration is another important feature and should be taken into account during the catalyst design. Bifunctional catalytic materials with a hierarchically porous network are favorable as they supply plentiful channels and open spaces for electrolyte infiltration and reactant diffusion as well as the gaseous product release. Besides, electrical conductivity is also vital. Elemental incorporation or hybridization with other conductive counterparts can accelerate the electron migration rate. The advances in rational engineering of bifunctional nano-electrodes/nano-catalysts emphasize three general approaches as listed in Fig. 6 and are discussed below. 4.1 Morphological/surface engineering The morphological nano-structuring can tailor and manipulate the physicochemical properties of active components, which reinforces the electrochemical capability. Several microstructures such as nanosheets, nanorods, nanowires, nano-flowers, and nanospheres have become a hot research topic due to their large specific surface area, rapid mass/ion diffusion, and unique stability during oxidation reactions. Rational engineering of catalytic surfaces increases the number of active sites and optimizes the adsorption/desorption properties [131–133]. Surface morphologies with one-dimensional (1D), two-dimensional (2D), and 3D nanostructures can broaden the active site exposure and control the electron transfer paths, which significantly benefits the overall efficiency of HWE systems. Surface engineering approaches involve surface morphology nano-structuring, crystallographic tailoring, and defect engineering (e.g., edge sites, heteroatom doping, and vacancies). The vacancies in synergistic electrolysis configurations strengthen the activity by supplying adsorption sites for the reactants, adjusting the adsorption energy of reaction intermediates and promoting the electron transport rate. Oxygen vacancy-rich Vo-Co3O4 for HMF electrooxidation displayed a high electrocatalytic performance. The time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry analysis elucidated that the OH– could occupy the Vo during the anodic electrooxidation reaction of HMF, thereby shortening the distance between OHad and reaction groups. The as-synthesized Vo-Co3O4 revealed lower reaction barriers for the rate-determining step from 5-hydroxymethyl-2- furancarboxylic acid to 2-formyl-5-furancarboxylic acid (1.17 eV) compared to vacancy-free Co3O4, manifesting that the OH– filled into Vo optimized the reaction kinetics (Figs. 7(a)–(c) ) [143]. Heteroatomic doping can deform the original crystal lattice, engineer the d-band centers and induce the local electron redistribution. This may be ascribed to the differences in electronegativity between the substituted atoms and introduced heteroatoms and differences in atomic radii. Such variations significantly reinforce the electrocatalytic activity of dopants and neighboring atoms. Liu et al. [117] presented the in-situ growth of P,W-co-doped Co3N nanowire arrays on Ni foam (NF) skeleton (PW-Co3N NWA/NF) for HzOR. The extended X-ray absorption fine-structure spectroscopy (EXAFS) findings certified that the incorporated W substituted the Co sites and bound with the N and P species, enabling more favorable N2H4 adsorption on PW-Co3N nanocomposite. The PW-Co3N determining step was desorption of *N2 to N2 rather than *NHNH to *N2H in the case of Co3N. Consequently, the P,W-co-doping could regulate the electronic structure of Co3N and accelerate the thermodynamic behavior of the dehydrogenation process during HzOR (Fig. 7(d)) [117]. The gas evolution reactions across the liquid/gas/solid triphasic interface and generation of gas bubbles at high current densities may intensively prohibit electron transport and liquid mass diffusion and constrict the catalytic active sites. This negatively affects the catalytic performance and stability. It is critical to reasonably upregulate the wetting state of an electrode/electrocatalyst building. Porous superhydrophilic surfaces under air ensure easy access to electrolyte ions and reactants, while superaerophobic surfaces in water accelerate the escape of gas bubbles from exposed surfaces during gas evolution processes. Superhydrophilic/superaerophobic frameworks promote the reaction kinetics and strengthen the catalytic performance [144]. Hierarchical porous 3D nanostructures expedite mass diffusion during electrooxidation processes, supply abundant open spaces with large active surface areas, and reinforce the utilization rate of active sites [145]. For example, Liao et al. [86] designed an integrated low-cost electrode with remarkable wettability composed of Ni NPs embedded on a hierarchically porous carbon wood (CW) scaffold for UOR with an improved performance (Fig. 8(a) ). The highly graphitized CW framework enhanced the electrical conductivity and tuned the exposure of active NiOOH species, promoting catalytic activity. The mastoid-like morphologies strengthened the hydrophilicity of the electrode, thereby boosting the accessibility of ions, enlarging the solid-liquid interface and active surface area, reducing the gas bubble shielding, and accelerating the reaction kinetics (Fig. 8(b)). Alongside, the hierarchical architectures with favorable aerophobicity could minimize the gas bubble adhesion and speed up the disengagement of small N2 and CO2 bubbles (Figs. 8(c) and (d)). The as-obtained Ni0.05/CW displayed a high UOR activity in an alkaline electrolyte, acquiring a voltage of 1.36 V vs. RHE to yield 10 mA cm–2 and illustrating a robust long-term electrocatalytic stability over 60 h (Figs. 8(e)–(g)). The theoretical calculation analyses indicated that the NiOOH centers could efficiently adsorb the key intermediates of the UOR process (NH2 * and CO*), proposing soft breakage of C–N bonding after the surface reconstruction step of the Ni0.05/CW catalyst. The corresponding density of state (DOS) calculations demonstrated less occupation at the Fermi level in the case of NiOOH compared with that of metal Ni, ensuring optimized adsorption strength of major intermediate molecules (Fig. 8(h)). In another study, cobalt hydroxide@hydroxysulfide nanosheet arrays supported on carbon paper (Co(OH)2@HOS/CP) were fabricated by an electrodeposition method and a simple surface sulfurization treatment [146]. The advantageous porous core-shell frameworks with numerous open windows not only enlarged the active surface area but also enabled abundantly exposed active sites and accelerated the mass transfer of ions and the release of resulting H2 gas as well as liquid products (Figs. 9(a)–(c) ). Benefiting from the composition regulation, surface characteristics, and chemistry of Co(OH)2, the bifunctional electrode promoted H2 production and simultaneously transformed methanol into valuable formate. Moreover, the electro-integrated two-electrode electrolyzer cell-directed HWE system yielded 10 mA cm−2 at a cell voltage of 1.497 V with 100% FE for both anodic and cathodic reactions (Figs. 9(d)–(f)). Similar hierarchical electrodes have been recently presented such as branch-like Mo-doped Ni3 S2 nano-forest on NF [147], hierarchical wire-on-sheet architecture-like Ni(OH)2 frameworks with optimized cerium doping [148], and unique fluorine-incorporated Ni(OH)2 nanosheets/Ni3 S2 nanorods composite [149]. A freestanding Ni-based multi-component (Ni NCNA): 1D nanorods-confined 2D nanoflake arrays were obtained via hydrothermal reaction and thermal annealing strategy under the H2/Ar atmosphere [150]. The resultant bifunctional electrode was superhydrophilic, allowing good electrolyte wettability and guaranteeing a rapid release of gas bubbles (Figs. 9(h) and (i)). The cordial connection between nanoflakes and nanorods created highways for electron transport. The strong collaborative effect of Ni-relevant multi-component enhanced the electrocatalytic process kinetics. Therefore, the obtained Ni NCNA electrode displayed an impressive electrocatalytic performance toward both HER and HzOR in alkaline solutions. Specifically, the constructed electrolytic cell-based HWE system utilizing the bifunctional Ni NCNA electrode as the anode and cathode in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/0.3 mol L−1 N2H4 electrolyte acquired 10 mA cm−2 at an ultra-small cell voltage of 23 mV and delivered an industrial electrocatalytic current density of 892 mA cm−2 with a low input voltage of 0.485 V (Figs. 9(j) and (k)). Cao's group obtained a unique hierarchical 3D architecture of leaf thorn-like bifunctional NiCoP directly on a conductive carbon cloth (CC) (NiCoP/CC) via a simple hydrothermal method and phosphorization treatment. Such a design provided good electrical contact and robust mechanical adherence between the active component and the underlying current collector. The microporous architectures and flexible features of CC not only promoted electrolyte inundation and gaseous product dissipation but also ensured the proper loading of active components on the whole active area. The energy-saving UOR/HER synergistic electrolysis system required a cell potential of only 1.42 V to reach 10 mA cm−2, which was less than the minimum potential of OWS (1.58 V). The adsorption properties of organic molecules on the catalyst surface and the corresponding kinetics of catalytic reaction can be stabilized by vacancies due to the formation of abundant active species caused by the surface reconstruction. The vacancy engineering induces fluctuations in the atomic relaxation at the boundaries and controls the local electron density. Vacancies in transition metal compounds can boost the catalytic performance through electronic structure modification [151]. For example, incorporating high-valence W boosted the catalytic activity of Ni active sites (Ni-WO x ) for UOR, enabling record-fast reaction kinetics [87]. Results demonstrated that the W dopant optimized the charge redistribution of Ni atoms, hence facilitating the occurrence of high-valence Ni3+ sites and promoting the interfacial catalytic reaction. Strikingly, the collected Fourier transform (FT) of EXAFS patterns demonstrated stronger Ni-W correlation and coordination geometry, in which all the W atoms were surrounded by adjacent Ni atoms (Figs. 10(a) and (b) ). Moreover, the presence of O-vacancies in bulk brought the synergetic effect of quicker electron mobility and improvement of catalytic activity (Figs. 10(c)−(e)). The establishment of metal cation vacancies was also employed. Ultra-thin NiFeRh nanosheet arrays with Rh doping were directly grown on NF via an hydrothermal growth approach as a bifunctional electrode for the UOR/HER synergistic electrolysis system (Figs. 10(f)−(h)) [152]. The positive shift of the p-band modified the binding strength of adsorbed intermediates. More importantly, the DFT calculation results revealed that the abundant O-vacancies favored the adsorption feature of urea molecules with high adsorption-free energy, implying improved UOR kinetics (Fig. 10(i)). As expected, the configured urea-mediated synergistic electrolysis system exhibited 10 mA cm−2 with a potential of 1.35 V, which was 105 mV less than that of the urea-free system (Figs. 10(j) and (k)). The anchored Rh atoms on the porous NiFe-LDH network enhanced the electronic structure, providing further optimization of adsorbed species. Furthermore, the N vacancies-enriched Ce-doped Ni3N hierarchical nanosheets on CC scaffolding (Ce-Ni3N@CC) could modulate the flat-footed UOR kinetics, particularly the stiff rate-determine CO2 release step [153]. DFT results illustrated that the rich N-vacancies in the Ce-Ni3N@CC electrode stabilized the adsorption energy of CO2 species during the rate-determining step and influenced the initial adsorption configuration of urea molecules, revealing superior UOR catalytic performance. Therefore, the UOR/HER flow hybrid electrolyzer performed well with low operational potential and remarkable stability. Interestingly to note, combining the crystalline-amorphous structural characteristics can retain their inherent features, thereby reinforcing the electrocatalytic performance. These novel complexes with sufficient interfaces offer more unsaturated active sites for catalysis proceeding and induce favorable charge redistribution to tune the electron structure [154]. Their strong interface interactions can afford more active sites, promote the absorption of reactants, and assist the breaking of chemical bonds to improve the catalytic activity [155,156]. In this context, a unique hierarchical 3D porous crystalline Ni(OH)2-amorphous NiMoO x nanocomposite was constructed on NF (Ni(OH)2-NiMoO x /NF) through a ZnO template-directed electrolytic deposition process and subsequent KOH etching treatment (Figs. 11(a)–(e) ) [157]. The phasic transformation induced by the KOH soaking operation improved the reaction kinetics, realizing excellent electrocatalytic activity (Fig. 11(f)). The enhanced anodic UOR competence of bifunctional Ni(OH)2-NiMoO x /NF electrode could drive the urea-assisted H2 production, needing merely 1.42 V to attain 10 mA cm−2 for the synergistic electrolysis system (Fig. 11(g)). The existence of multiple interfaces between crystalline and amorphous regions presented sufficient electron shooting and many reaction areas. Concerning the morphology and physicochemical properties adjusting, many feasible paths have been exercised to construct 3D architectures for boosting the mass transfer, enlarging the surface area, and increasing the porosity of electrodes/electrocatalysts for manipulating the utilization of active sites, and downsizing NPs. Besides, introducing numerous defects, engineering complex hybridization, and creating alloys can mutate the physicochemical properties of active nanomaterials. 4.2 Interface/heterojunction construction The ensemble effect generally occurs in multi-component active compounds, especially throughout heterojunctions. To develop more effective bifunctional electrodes/electrocatalysts, the intrinsic structure of oxidizable organic molecules shouldn't be ignored. Hence, it is supposed that well-designed active materials with local electrophilic and nucleophilic active centers may hearten the adsorption and decomposition of organic/biomass substrate molecules. Unlike the electronic effect, the ensemble effect strongly relies on a distinctive component, in which the adsorption properties of reaction intermediates are optimized by the integrated adsorption sites with regulated coordination environments [158–166]. Single atomic nano-catalysts (SACs) have recently aroused much interest owing to their nearly 100% atom effectiveness and ultra-high electrocatalytic activities. SACs can be manufactured by encapsulating metal ions on suitable scaffolding such as carbon, 2D LDHs, and other matrices, offering an intuitive pathway to higher stability by handicapping dissolution and/or agglomeration. The interactions and coordination environment between implanted atomic sites and adjoining atoms of support or other contiguous metal atoms play an important role in promoting electrocatalytic capability [167]. It is thus significant to choose a suitable conductive scaffold that can strongly interact with the embedded atomic sites yet does not compromise the catalytic performance. For example, single atomic rhodium sites were supported on Ni-V LDH nanosheets network (Rh/NiV-LDH) as multi-functional electrocatalysts were prepared through an easy ethylene glycol (EG)-assisted solvothermal approach (Figs. 11(h)–(k)) [168]. Obtained DFT outcomes signified that the monodispersed single atomic Rh sites, which were vertically facing the O atoms of underlying LDHs could modulate the electronic structure of parent NiV-LDH platforms and suppress the reaction barriers of the Heyrovsky step for the HER process. Simultaneously, the atomic Rh sites regulated the adsorption and activation processes of urea molecules and prompted the intermediates (i.e., CO*/NH*). This could decrease the energy barrier of the rate-determining step and enhance the UOR activity (Fig. 11(l)). Moreover, the UOR/HER hybrid electrolyzer employing the binder-free Rh/NiV-LDH electrodes as both the anode and cathode in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.33 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2 electrolyte solutions required a small voltage of 1.471 V to deliver 100 mA cm–2, outperforming the OWS electrolyzer equipped with the Rh/NiV-LDH electrodes (Fig. 11(m)). The system displayed extreme bubbling on both sides, proposing an efficient path for large-scale energy-saving H2 release and urea-rich wastewater tidiness. Notably, heterostructures can create hetero-interfacial effects, endow abundant heterojunctions, modulate the electronic configurations, induce charge reconstruction, and afford many active centers for the absorption of reactants and intermediates, thus promoting the reaction kinetics. Minimal heteroatomic doping also possesses a great capability to regulate the valence state of active components. Regarding heterostructure engineering, dignified research efforts have been performed by increasing the constitutional complexity, tuning the electronic configurations, constructing multi-active phase compositions, and adjusting the surface functionality. Motivated by the electronic and ensemble effects, multiple components and hetero-structured nanomaterials can make up for the weakness of individual counterparts. Multi-component electrocatalysts can greatly facilitate the occurrence of reaction steps separately, thereby promoting the reaction kinetics and even optimizing the catalytic process pathway. As a representative example, Li et al. [169] explored high-entropy Pt18Ni26Fe15Co14Cu27/C catalysts for methanol oxidation reaction (MOR). It was observed theoretically that each component revealed a different role in the electrocatalysis process of methanol molecules. The analyzed projected DOS (PDOS) indicated that the Pt-5d occupied the deepest position could serve as an electron reservoir for the reduction process. Meanwhile, the dense Ni-3d and Co-3d orbitals near the EF improved the electron depletion center for MOR. Besides, the Fe-3d, Cu-3d, and Co-3d stabilized the MOR intermediates. The detected down-shifting of s and p orbitals confirmed the electron transfer from the Pt18Ni26Fe15Co14Cu27/C to methanol. This elucidated the favorable adsorption of methanol molecules on the Pt18Ni26Fe15Co14Cu27/C catalyst. As a result, a higher mass activity for MOR (15.04 A mg–1 Pt) than benchmarking Pt/C could be attained (Figs. 12(a) and (b) ) [169]. The commonly studied UOR pathway on most Ni-based electrocatalysts with the in-situ formed high-valence NiOOH derivatives as the actual catalytic centers is *CO(NH2)2 → *CO(NH·NH2) → *CO(NH·NH) → *CO(NH·N) → *CO(N2) → *CO(OH) + N2 → *CO(OH·OH) → *COO.
