However, a two-step reaction mechanism was recently triggered by Ni ferrocyanide (Ni2Fe(CN)6) electrode [170]. Such thermodynamically/kinetically reaction pathways with different rate-determining steps proceeded through the generation of ammonia species (H2O + CO2(CO(NH2)2 → 2NH3 + CO2) as an intermediate on the Ni sites and its subsequent decomposition into N2 (6OH– + 2NH3 → 6H2O + N2 + 6e–) on the Fe site (Fig. 12(c)) [170]. The in-situ synchrotron radiation Fourier transform infrared (SR-FT-IR) analysis illustrated the reaction intermediates on the catalyst surface. The corresponding absorption peaks at 2925 and 1203 cm–1 were largely assigned to the N–H stretching vibrations of *N=NH2 and C–O stretching vibrations of *OCONH2, respectively, evidencing the coexistence of two separated steps of UOR on Ni2Fe(CN)6 catalyst. Accordingly, the engineered (Ni2Fe(CN)6) electrode was able to facilitate the UOR process with higher activity than NiC2O4, enabling an anodic catalytic current density of 100 mA cm−2 at a potential of 1.35 V. Combined DFT results revealed that the enhanced intrinsic electrochemical performance of Ni2Fe(CN)6 was largely ascribed to the synergistic effect of Ni and Fe double-active sites. The UOR/HER electrolyzer was established in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/0.33 mol L−1 CO(NH2)2 solution to evaluate the energy-saving advantage of UOR on the Ni2Fe(CN)6 electrode. The system obtained 10 and 100 mA cm–2 with a cell potential of 1.38 and 1.50 V, respectively, whereas the OWS required cell potentials of 1.56 and 1.85 V, respectively. In addition, a stable H2 production was observed by such a devised UOR/HER cell with a FE of over 90%. The nano-interfaces enhance the electronic structure through an interfacial electron transfer owing to the synergy between integrated components. The adjusted electronic configurations in turn influence the overall electrochemical behavior. In the meantime, increasing the number of nano-interfaces elevates the number of accessible active sites, therefore boosting the catalytic activities [155,156]. Diversified heterointerfaces have been constructed to serve as bifunctional electrodes/electrocatalysts in the HWE system driving energy-saving H2 generation such as Co x P@NiCo-LDH hetero-nanosheet [49], Ni3 S2-Ni3P/NF [134], carbon-modified MoO2-FeP heterostructures (MoO2-FeP@C) [135], NiSe@NiO x core-shell nanowires [171], NiCo LDH nanosheets modified Cu nanowire arrays (NiCoNSs/CuNWs) [172], CoS2-MoS2 [173], CoMn/CoMn2O4 [97], hetero-porous MoS2/Ni3S2 [174], and heterostructured Ni2P/MoO2/NF nanorod arrays [175]. Hetero-structured nanomaterials supported on 3D current collectors can guide the growth of hierarchical 3D frameworks, intensify the electron/mass migration, enlarge the active site exposure, and modulate the adsorption of reactants and intermediate species [49–52,176–178]. For example, Fe-doped Ni2P/CoP heterostructure nanosheets stabilized on N-doped ultra-thin carbon layers (Fe-CoNiP@NC) were constructed on NF substrate via soaking, ion exchange, and annealing strategy [179]. The resulting Fe-CoNiP@NC electrode revealed outstanding electrocatalytic activities for catalyzing both HzOR and HER in an alkaline seawater solution. Because of the synergistic effect of heterostructured components, foreign metal doping, and carbon encapsulation with N moieties, the obtained Fe-CoNiP@NC could maintain excellent activity and stability in HzOR synergizing hybrid seawater catalysis. The constructed two-electrode hybrid seawater electrolysis cell achieved 1000 mA cm−2 with an ultra-small potential of 0.56 V and preserved a stable catalytic current response of 500 mA cm−2 for 100 h with almost 100% FE. Hierarchically nano-structured Ni-Fe bimetallic nitride (Ni2Fe2N) with abundant heterointerfaces and good electronic conductivity was developed through a hydrothermal-nitridation treatment approach [180]. The thus-synthesized Ni2Fe2N electrode illustrated high intrinsic electrocatalytic performance toward HzOR with high electrocatalytic current signal (1017 mA cm−2 at 0.3 V), exceptional long-term stability, and nearly 100% selectivity for the Faradaic N2H4 degradation proceeding a four-electron pathway. Generally speaking, the core-shell heterostructures can further reinforce the synergism between active components by expanding the interfacial contact regions across heterojunctions. Some heterostructured core-shell architectures-based bifunctional electrodes/electrocatalysts such as Pd@RhPd nano-dendrites [181], heterostructured Mo-NiCoP@NiCoP/ Ni x Co y H2PO2 nanorods [182], crystalline Ni@amorphous NiP anchored active carbon matrix (Ni@NiP/C) [183], Cu/NiCu nanowires [184], crystalline Ni5P4@amorphous NiO x nanosheets [185], and Ni@Ni2P nanotube arrays [186], were presented with efficient electrocatalytic activities. The electrons are redistributed across heterointerface regions, stabilizing the adsorption energy of reactants and intermediate-containing species for regulating the catalysis efficiency. Alloying is a conventional strategy to produce effective heterostructures by blending two or more metallic components or metallic and non-metallic components. This is predominantly different from the doping technique, where dopants only account for a little content without changing the original crystal structures [169]. A bifunctional Ni-Mo alloy nanotube electrocatalyst was fabricated by using a hydrothermal-annealing treatment technique to produce pure H2 with the assistance of anodic UOR in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte [187]. The DFT calculation analyses claimed that the Ni centers could serve as the main promoter for the HER process, whereas the MO sites significantly facilitated the chemisorption of water molecules and O–H bond cleavage. The novel HWE configuration combining both the HER and UOR synergistic reaction processes remarkably reduced the overall potential to 1.43 V as compared with the traditional OWS (1.59 V) for outputting 10 mA cm−2, this was largely related to the enhanced metallicity and tunable electronic structures. 4.3 Electronic structure regulation Specifically, local electronic structure manipulation and/or rational composition amendment is a highly desirable method to endow the intrinsic bifunctional electrocatalytic activity and reinforce the synergistic effect of electrodes/electrocatalysts for driving HWE systems. Active components with favorable surface electronic structures modulate the binding strengths between active catalytic centers and reaction intermediates, hence minimizing the reaction barriers of the rate-determining steps [188,189], Ions or heteroatomic doping, structural defects, and multi-active nano-integration produce local electron redistribution, which activates the neighboring atoms to be catalytically active sites by changing their chemical states. Electron redistribution contributes to the overall charge transfer process from the electrolyte/electrode interfaces to the adsorbed species. Chemical bondings are closely associated with electronic configurations and chemical coordination environments. The optimized electronic structure facilitates the breaking and stretching of existing chemical bonding and creates desirable electroactive species [190–192]. Maximizing the polarity of chemical bonds assists the active site establishment due to simple dissociation in alkaline solutions. Electronic effects originate from the chemical environment alteration of active materials by manipulating the electron structure and charge distribution, hence expediting the reaction rate and decreasing the energy barrier. Incorporating multiple components with various electronic characteristics such as multi-metallic active species, conductive support, and functional ligands can adjust the electronic effect [193–198]. The difference in the Fermi levels of various nano-integrated components improves the electronic interactions at interface regions, therefore inducing a built-in electric field. Such an induced built-in electric field may conquer the problem related to the sluggish kinetics of multi-electron transfer processes and directly influence the charge density near active centers to promote intrinsic electrocatalytic activity [194–198]. The structure or morphology modification may also induce an electronic effect. Strikingly apparent, the surface electronic configurations hold a significant impact concerning the active site formation and contribute to overall catalytic efficiency. Introducing non-metallic elements such as sulfur (S), N, oxygen (O), boron (B), fluorine (F), phosphorus (P), and selenium (Se) can enhance the electronic structure of active materials and boost the electrocatalytic capability [12,124], For example, amidinothiourea and thioacetamide-mediated N-doped NiS/NiS2 (N-NiS/NiS2) nanostructures were designed through a sulfuration process. As an efficient heterogeneous electrocatalyst, the resulting N-NiS/NiS2 nanocomposite with a large surface area, favorable electronic effect, and potent interfacial coupling exhibited bifunctional electrolysis properties toward the HER and UOR in terms of catalytic activity, accelerated kinetics, and stability performance. The as-designed N-NiS/NiS2 (+,–)-based electrolytic cell could drive the electro-integrated UOR/HER couple in the HWE system, yielding 10 mA cm−2 with a minimum potential of 1.5 V, less than that of conventional OWS system (1.62 V@10 mA cm−2) [199]. Multi-functional electrocatalytic electrode-like P-doped CoC3 nanosheets on the Co foam skeleton (P-CoC3/CF) with desirable electronic structure were fabricated via a hydrothermal-annealing process [200]. The electrode revealed high catalytic performances toward the HER and HzOR in alkaline electrolytes. The P-CoC3/CF(+,−) two-electrode cell catalyzed the electro-coupled HzOR/HER synergistic processes in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/0.3 mol L–1 N2H4 supporting electrolyte, reaching merely 0.13 V to gain 100 mA cm−2. The DFT analyses clarified that the low electronegative P atoms reduced the electron-withdrawing strength of Co−P bonding compared with the Co−O coordination, enabling more enhancements in the adsorption properties. The analyzed free energy of the rate-determining step for the HzOR was boosted on the P-doped surface higher than the intrinsic CoC3 surface, hence maximizing the catalytic activity. Heteroatomic S modification into metallic Ni(OH)2 nanosheet structures accomplished ternary amendments in electronic structures, active sites, and electrical behavior [201]. After S incorporation, the collected Ni K-edge X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) patterns and solid-state magic-angle spinning NMR spectra revealed a negative shift of the absorption threshold to lower energy, verifying an increase in electron concentration compared with the pristine Ni(OH)2 (Figs. 13(a) and (b) ). The introduced S anions weakened the covalent bonds and the delocalized congealed electrons due to the smaller electronegativity of S than O and larger atomic radius (Fig. 13(c)). The difference in energy levels of such a single-phase electrocatalyst regulated the charge redistribution, therefore modifying the adsorption of reactant molecules and improving the catalytic behavior. This proved efficient electron transport, rapid CO2 desorption rate from catalytic centers, and large exposure of catalytic sites (Fig. 13(d)), hence, readily optimizing the electronic structure. Besides, the S species could reduce the energy barrier of intermediate occurrence and boost the overall UOR process (Figs. 13(e) and (f)). Dual doping of metallic and non-metallic atoms seems to be more advantageous compared to single-atomic doping. Thus, multiple doping is expected to offer more attractive features for electrocatalysis because of the induced synergistic effect between different incorporated atoms. The electronic structures and intrinsic electrocatalytic activity can be further enhanced via dual-doping. For instance, hairy-shaped Ni nanowires on carbon nanofibers incorporating N,S dual dopants (Ni/N,S-CNFs) were obtained by an electrospinning process and a carbonization treatment in the presence of melamine and trithiocyanuric acid salts as the N and S source, respectively. The resulting Ni/N,S-CNFs catalyst with modified surface composition presented enhanced catalytic properties for UOR compared with the Ni/CNFs. The role of dual N/S anions doping was confirmed to improve the electrical conductivity owing to synergistic electronic interactions [202]. In addition, multi-channel hollow Ru/P dual-doped NiMoO4 arrayed nanorods supported on NF scaffold (Ru/P-NiMoO4@NF) were developed via a hydrothermal reaction and thermal phosphorization process to expose large electrochemical surface active area (ECSA) for hybrid seawater electrolysis (Figs. 13(g)–(i)) [203]. The optimized multi-channel Ru/P-NiMoO4@NF electrode approached a large current density of 3000 and 1000 mA cm−2 at 0.23 and 1.46 V for the HER and UOR in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH and 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/0.5 mol L−1 CO(NH2)2 electrolyte solutions, respectively. Upon the application of Ru/P-NiMoO4@NF electrodes for directing the electro-integrated UOR/HER reactions in a hybrid seawater catalysis system, a potential of 1.73 V was needed to acquire 500 mA cm−2 with supreme long-term stability up to 145 h to sustain a catalytic current response of 100 mA cm−2, exceeding the commercial Pt/C//RuO2 couple (Figs. 13(j)–(l)). In-depth DFT results demonstrated that the co-doped Ru/P atoms modified the d-band center and could simultaneously improve the absorption properties of reactant species. Besides, the DOS across the Fermi level was enhanced with the introduction of Ru and P dopants, implying abundant charge carriers participating in the catalytic process and remarkably improved catalytic activity. The proper DOS near the Fermi level could enhance the electric conductivity and accelerate the interfacial electron transport kinetics (Fig. 13(m)). The important role of non-metallic anions can be elucidated by their robust electronegativity, which encourages them to gain electrons from neighboring atoms and then cooperate with the metal centers to apprehend positively charged protons, resulting in a better electrochemical activity. Upon the enrollment of anions or foreign elements, the original metal atoms distanced from each other, and subsequently their corresponding interfacial interactions would be debilitated. This causes lattice expansion and tensile strain which in turn impacts the electronic properties. In light of the combined merits of suitable morphological, structural, compositional, and electronic effects, multi-functional nano-electrodes/nano-catalysts usually delivered enhanced catalytic performances in terms of catalytic current response, fast reaction kinetics, small onset potentials, and reinforced long-term stability. Besides, multi-component nanomaterials and binary or ternary complexed/alloyed metals, high entropy alloys represent a type of advanced alloys that may become a research hot spot soon. 5 Theoretical calculation attributes As a suitable computational tool with affordable cost, high accuracy and reliability, DFT has been widely investigated to examine electrochemical water electrolysis in alkaline conditions. It affords detailed information about the structure, energy, and electronic configurations of a given combination of molecules or atoms. Theoretical simulations based on the DFT technique can be performed to evaluate the band structures of active components to gain more insights into the kinetics of catalytic processes [121–123]. The proposed metal model with a certain number of atoms is usually employed to estimate the Fermi level of crystal facets and predict the possible electroactive sites for activating and absorbing the reactant molecules. Gibbs free energy scheme represents an important indicator to elucidate various electrochemical catalysis steps and identify the corresponding energy of each step during the whole catalytic reaction process. The thermodynamics of the reaction process control the activation energy barrier between steps, hence optimizing the overpotential. The adsorption energies of reaction intermediates strongly correlate with the composition, structure, and defects [193–198]. The dopants and defects may serve as active sites for reinforcing the adsorption of intermediates. Examples are provided in Figs. 14(a)–(d) , which display the UOR, ethanol oxidation reaction (EOR), and MOR free energy diagrams calculated over different catalytic surfaces. Bader charge analyses also give more details regarding the adsorption of reaction intermediates during various electrochemical processes (Figs. 14(e)–(f)). Side-by-side, the information on the conduction and valence (lowest unoccupied/highest occupied energy molecular orbital levels) can identify the Fermi level of introduced catalytic models according to the band configurations. The DFT calculations of van der Waals heterojunction systems or Schottky heterojunctions demonstrate that favorable charge density redistribution can be induced at interface regions, allowing more understanding of the electron density and electron transfer kinetics of the heterojunction model and Schottky barrier. The electronic interface generated by rectifying the contact integrated components constructs the surface electric field and boosts the catalytic behavior. Because the DFT approach evaluates material properties according to the functional relationship to electronic configuration, it is intrinsically effective for analyzing the charge distribution. The DOS is a semi-quantitative parameter for monitoring the electronic conductivity of electrochemical active compounds and can estimate the occupied electronic energy levels after structural optimization. Smaller bandgaps between the conduction and valence bands imply higher DOS near the Fermi level, ensuring a large concentration of charge carriers and maximizing electronic conductivity. Figs. 14(g)–(i) give a straightforward example of utilizing the DOS to explore the charge transfer kinetics in electrocatalytic reactions. The total DOS can be further decomposed into the PDOS of each electronic orbital configuration, which illustrates the electronic band structures of various components. These indicators are strongly related to the electrochemical characteristics of active compounds. 6 Selective oxidation reactions of organic/biomass substrates Selective oxidation of oxidizable organic/biomass substrate molecules has shown great potential as the kinetically preferable pathway to the conventional water catalysis system. These anodic oxidation reactions can mitigate the impasse of wastewater pollution, create value-added species with high transformation efficiency, and realize simultaneous green H2 generation or decomposition of contaminants. Nevertheless, these small molecules must be supplied from torrential reserves in nature or simply industrialized at a reasonable cost. In addition, neither these oxidizable molecules nor their corresponding products should palpably interfere with the HER. The following sections emerge comprehensive overview and discussions of recently introduced organic/biomass substrates in HWE technology for energy-saving H2 generation. Hence, it is highly desirable to explore aqueous hybrid electrolyzer cells having extra-economic advantages but it is still extremely challenging to design cost-effective, exceptionally active, and selective nanomaterials to efficiently drive the electrooxidation reactions of small oxidizable molecules into partially oxidative products and achieve substantial energy saving compared to traditional OWS. Recent research has focused on transition metal complexes as the most exciting electrodes/electrocatalysts owing to their considerable advantages including, rich redox reactions, massive availability, and excellent anticorrosion properties in alkaline solutions. Additionally, precious noble metal-based electrocatalysts and their bimetal alloyed systems have been also applied to electro-catalyze various oxidation reactions and produce H2 via energy-saving pathways. Up to now, formidable research endeavors have outlined the reaction mechanisms/pathways of small molecule electrooxidation reactions by integrating various characterization methods and theoretical calculations to examine intermediate species and final products occurring during reactions. 6.1 Alcohols synergizing HWE systems With the promising emergence of electrochemical technology, oxidation of alcohols such as CH3OH, C2H5OH, glycerol, and BA, etc. has been extensively researched owing to their potential deployment in direct alcohol fuel cells (DAFCs), transformation of biomass derivatives, and soft chemical manufacturing. Aliphatic and aromatic alcohol-based biomass synergizing HWE systems possess long-range raw material sources, illustrate low thermodynamic equilibrium potentials, and facilitate the formation of extremely pure value-added chemicals (e.g., carboxylic acids and/or aldehydes). The attempt to electro-oxidize alcohols coupled with the H2 production path was first proposed in 1948 [204]. It was found that the theoretical voltages of various alcohol oxidation reactions were lower than 0.1 V vs. RHE, implying their potential to substitute the anodic OER and promote water splitting. Electro-integrating the anodic oxidation reactions of alcohols and HER through the HWE system decreases the CO poisoning of anodic electrocatalyst and corresponding suppression caused by the complete oxidative degradation of alcohols [205]. Due to the impressive overall FE of an electrolytic cell, the combination of alcohol oxidation reactions and the HER process has been widely studied and investigated. However, the co-generation of high-purity chemicals at the anode and H2 at the cathode is restrained by the dispersive and complicated electrooxidation reaction pathways [12]. The in-depth interest in boosting the reaction kinetics and adjusting selectivity to specific valuable species is vital to construct effective and mightily applicable electrocatalytic nanomaterials for alcohol synergizing HWE. The overall oxidation reaction pathway of alcoholic substrates can be identified as follows [206]: (20) RCH2OH + H2O → 2H2 + RCOOH Generally speaking, the oxidation process of many alcoholic substances includes CO elimination as the rate-determining step [70]. In this context, the CO oxidation mechanism was proposed by Watanabe-Motoo, articulating the bifunctional influence of PtRu bimetallic electrocatalyst (Eq. (21)) [207]. (21) RuOH + PtCO → Ru + Pt + CO2 + H+ + e– Expressing the reaction mechanisms on a series of Pt/C modified with Ru sites as model catalysts were elucidated. It could be proposed that the adsorbed OH– ions on Ru sites with a narrow onset potential accelerated the oxidation of adsorbed CO on Pt centers. In the current decade, anodic alcohol electrooxidation/HER couples utilizing earth-abundant transition metal nano-compounds as efficient bifunctional electrodes/electrocatalysts have been extensively adopted to yield low-potential H2 formation (Table 2 ). The electro-catalytic oxidation of alcohol over NiOOH species takes place via two oxidation mechanisms (indirect and potential-dependent pathway). One is that electrocatalytic oxidation of alcohol was always known to occur through hydrogen atom transfer to NiOOH. More specifically, NiOOH active species were first generated and NiOOH gain α -H atom from (RCH2OH)ads, forming Ni(OH)2 that acted as the rate-determining step of alcohol electrooxidation (Eqs. (22)−(25)). Therefore, as long as the potential was positive, the applied potential has no significant impact on the kinetics and rate of alcohol electrooxidation. (22) OH− + Ni(OH)2 ↔ H2O + NiOOH (23) RCH2OHsol ↔ RCH2OHads (24) NiOOH + RCH2OHads → Ni(OH)2 + RCHOHads (rate-determining step) (25) 3NiOOH + RCHOHads + H2O → 3Ni(OH)2 + RCOOHsol The other mechanism which called potential-dependent pathway at more positive voltages compared with the indirect mechanism. In such a proposed pathway, hydride transferred from substrate to Ni4+ sites in NiOOH, could facilitate the oxidative dehydrogenation reactions over oxide/hydroxide electrocatalysts. 6.1.1 Methanol electrooxidation synergizing HWE systems Methanol collaborating HWE configuration can attain a relatively high H2 quantity by supplying a large electron number during the synergistic electrolysis [44−52]. On the other hand, partial methanol oxidation produces formic acid as a sold chemical, which can be widely applied for manufacturing rubber, leather, textiles, and pesticides [44−52]. Hence, the tradeoff between partial and full methanol electrooxidation reactions should be conducted according to candid material supply and certain industrial requirements. The activity tendency of various monometallic and bimetallic electrocatalytic surfaces was expressed by Tritsaris and Rossmeisl (Figs. 15(a) and (b) ) [208]. The paradigms in the white zone represent the most active electrocatalysts with optimal OH− and CO adsorption energies, proposing an efficient transmission from water and methanol to OH− and CO species, respectively. It can be seen that the complexed Pt2Cu/Pt, Pt3Ru/Ru, and Pt3Sn catalytic surfaces were supposed to display a high performance for methanol electrooxidation. Besides, the revised methanol electrooxidation reaction was also presented, in which an irrelevant CO oxidation would take place on the Pt catalytic sites. Instead, the Pt-Ru coordinations are the wholeheartedly active centers for the oxygen insertion step, promoting the immediate reaction mechanism and occurrence of formate. Ligand and strain effects can boost the methanol oxidation performance of catalysts which may be attributed to the enhancements in surface electronic structures through coordination interactions and surface strain caused by the change in metal bond distances [209]. The change in the p-band width may control the chemical properties such as the adsorption energy of hydrogen. Moreover, the ensemble effect is also another perspective contributing to the modulation of methanol oxidation activity [210]. The surface electronic structures of multi-component nanomaterials can be controlled via ligand and strain effects, adjusting the p-band of intermetallic compounds. The anodic oxidation reaction of methanol molecules is usually expressed as: (26) OH− + CH3OH → 2H2 + HCOO− In such a case, the Oads species are plentiful at the anode side with different structures, which support the interactions with electrocatalytic components to strengthen the MOR. Besides, the Hads species resulting from water electrolysis are harvested in the form of H2 at the cathode side. Thus, a high content of Oads species can be produced and even participate in the catalytic process through the engineering of advanced MOR synergizing HWE systems. This accelerates the selective conversion of methanol molecules into the targeted product and simultaneously yields low-potential H2. To better display the enigma of MOR synergizing HWE technology and earn a better understanding of the influence of various structure-activity correlations on catalytic activity. Multivalent hetero-nanocrystals-like Cu2Se/Co3Se4 architectures with dense heterojunctions as charge transport channels and highly enriched lattice defects were prepared via the interfacial engineering of the Cu/Co electronic structures by using a one-pot hot injection method (Figs. 15(c) and (d)). The as-obtained nanocomposite could selectively catalyze methanol molecules to formate, approaching a low onset potential of 1.04 V and yielding 10 mA cm−2 at a potential of 1.11 V with a high FE of 98%. Thus, competing against the sluggish OER and reducing the working potential as well as saving the energy consumption to produce pure H2 gas (Figs. 15(e) and (f)) [211]. The recorded Cu K-edge and Co K-edge XANES scans verified the construction of Cu2Se|Co3Se4 hetero-interfaces with noticeable lattice distortions induced by the engineered Cu2Se and Co3Se4 coupling in a hybridization state (Figs. 15(g) and (h)). This might establish the Cu–Se–Co bonding bridges as efficient charge-shooting channels for elastic electron transport. The DFT calculation outcomes revealed that the engineered Cu2Se/Co3Se4 heterojunctions with the hydroxylated (220) Cu2Se and (311) Co3Se4 surfaces and complex species (Cu*-OOH, Co*-OOH, and SeO x as synergistic active centers) could efficiently regulate the surface adsorption/dissociation of reactants and intermediates during methanol upgrading process and repress the formation of CO2 (Figs. 15(i) and (j)). The mechanism of methanol electrooxidation to formate is also proposed based on DFT calculations [178]. The authors demonstrated that the generation of M/OCH3 intermediate on the (102) NiSe exposed facets was thermodynamically much easier with a suitable energy of 0.64 eV to create NiSe/OCH3 than that of NiSe/HCOOOH (precursor of CO2/C3 2− formation). Results claimed that a low adsorption energy of −0.4 eV for NiSe/HCOOH confirmed a more selective access to formic acid instead of further oxidation to CO2. Surface reconstruction of catalysts into more electrocatalytically active species during the anodic reaction was deliberated to influence the overall performance. Studies claimed that the residual or adsorbed anionic species on the catalytic layers (e.g., NiOOH) improve the electronic configurations of active sites, enabling a higher activity [212]. Similarly, in the selective oxidation reaction of small organic molecules, the NiOOH active species have been also considered as effective catalytic active centers [213]. Furthermore, the chemical coordination of various anionic species and anionic doping may also optimize the anodic electrooxidation reactions of methanol molecules. Accordingly, the impact of TO x (T = P, S, and Se) oxyanions on the coordination environments of Ni sites was figured out to promote the catalysis of methanol molecules [214]. The residual oxyanions coordinating amorphous NiOOH were realized via an in-situ anodic electrochemical process, creating various local coordination environments of Ni sites. Experiments and theoretical characterizations demonstrated that the coordinated phosphate oxyanions could sufficiently tailor the d-band center of Ni sites and boost the Ni–O covalency, supporting the activity and selectivity of catalytic Ni species for methanol transformation into formate (Figs. 16(a) and (b) ). The amorphous NiOOH-PO x exhibited moderate adsorption properties of OH* and methanol guest molecules and favored the formulation of CH3O* products (Figs. 16(c1)–(c3), (d1)–(d3), and (e1)–(e3)). Consequently, the defect-rich NiP x -R catalyst with a large ECSA gained 400 mA cm−2 under MOR conditions at a potential of 1.4 V (Figs. 16(f) and (g)). The adsorption/desorption behavior of methanol molecules and the formation of active sites were also elaborated through in-situ tests. Fu's group [215] reported monodisperse carbon nanotubes (CNTs) hybridized hollow NiSe NPs (h-NiSe/CNTs) to drive the selective oxidation of methanol to more valuable product and promote the green H2 production with a large and steady current response (≍ 345 mA cm−2) under a high FE (> 95%). The systematically and deeply investigated XPS and EXAFS measurements signified that the hydroxylation/oxidation was gradually enriched on the NiSe surface, forming Ni–OH and SeO x species during different steps of the MOR process. Briefly, Ni2+ was oxidized to high-valence Ni3+ during MOR, which was then combined with the OH* in the electrolyte to produce NiOOH. Meanwhile, Se oxidized to SeO x species, facilitating the catalyst reconfiguration and directing the non-Faradaic process of MOR (Figs. 16(h)–(i)). In addition, the in-situ Raman patterns revealed that the constructed NiOOH species as the main active sites accelerated the first stage of MOR to quickly attain Ni–OCH3 (Figs. 16(j1)–(j2)). Hence, initiating the subsequent methanol activation stages. Impressively, the NiOOH active species failed to further electro-oxidize formic acid into CO/CO2, manifesting a good selectivity toward methanol conversion into formic acid. The DFT findings signalized that the abundant generated NiOOH and SeO x species under an equilibrium surface state could synergistically improve the Ni p-band center to reach the optimal adsorption of methanol molecules and prohibit their overoxidation to CO2. Therefore, it can be reasonably contemplated that the catalyst reconfiguration by OH* species is possibly ascribed to the decomposition of water molecules during the MOR synergizing HWE system. Supposing that the OH* comes from the alcoholic hydroxyl group of methanol or the OH– activation inside the electrolyte solution, the slight decrease of OH* concentration due to continuous exhaustion of OH– during the electrochemical catalysis process may adversely impact the long-term stability. The synergistic effect of smart morphological features and electronic modulation may endow the tailored nanomaterial with exceptional electrochemical activity and stability. Developing an open scaffold architecture with well-arranged building units on a conductive substrate not only shuns the use of additional polymeric binders but also enlarges the contact area, and favors electrolyte infiltration and gas release. In this regard, Jiao and co-workers obtained Mo-modified Co4N nanoarrays (Mo-Co4N) with abundant catalytic sites and optimized electronic synergy as a bifunctional electrode for MOR synergizing HWE system and concurrent electrolytic H2 production. The assembled Mo-Co4N(+,–) electrolytic cell could drive the electro-coupled MOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, delivering appreciable catalytic activity (10 mA cm−2 at 1.427 V) better than that of traditional OWS configuration (10 mA cm−2 at 1.596 V) with a high FE of 100% [216]. Oxophilic materials such as TMOs, TMPs, and transition metal tellurides can promote water dissociation owing to their suitable adsorption characteristics of reaction intermediates. For example, the robust interaction between Co-3d and Te-5p chemical states caused by the covalent Co–Te chemical bonds enhanced the catalytic activity and stability toward H2 generation even in an acidic environment [217]. Moreover, zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIF-67)-67 derived CoTe/NC nanospheres with ultra-fine Pt NPs were proposed as a bifunctional nano-catalyst for H2 production via MOR collaborating HWE system in an acidic electrolyte. Collected analyses revealed that the optimized electronic structures of the resulting Pt-CoTe/NC nanomaterial tuned the adsorption energies of CO and H*, providing a high electrocatalytic activity for MOR and HER [218]. Consequently, the devised Pt-CoTe/NC(+,–) electrolyzer driving MOR/HER synergistic electrolysis presented much better energy conversion efficiency than the established Pt-CoTe/ NC(+,–)-based OWS system, suggesting an energy-saving pathway for H2 generation. 6.1.2 Ethanol electrooxidation synergizing HWE systems Ethanol is of practical interest due to the merits of simple storage and natural availability. It can be synthesized at a reasonable energy cost via steam reforming of cellulosic substances or biomass fermentation [219]. Moreover, anodic EOR is essential to convert many biomass feedstocks into high-value species (e.g., acetic acid and ethyl acetate). The value-added acetic acid can be employed as an acidulant, pickling agent, acidity regulator, fragrance, etc. while ethyl acetate is used for manufacturing artificial leather and inks. Hence, the EOR synergizing the HWE system offers an important approach for producing green H2 with a lower potential (Table 2). The reaction mechanism of such synergistic electrolysis system can be outlined as follows: (27) Anodic reaction (EOR): 5OH– + C2H5OH → 4H2O + CH3COO– + 4e– (28) Cathodic reaction (HER): 4H2O + 4e– → 4OH– + 2H2 Overall (EOR/HER) co-electrolysis: (29) OH– + C2H5OH → 2H2 + CH3COO– The reaction energies of O–H, C–H, and C–C activation steps on the (111)Pt are depicted in Figs. 17(a) and (b) [220]. As can be seen, the activation of C–H bonds occurs around 0 V vs. RHE with the posterior activation of OH bonding of intermediates. Elevating the potential to 0.68 V vs. RHE can promote the C–C bond activation. Upon increasing the potential, dehydrogenation reactions become more exothermic, implying that the dehydrogenation steps may decrease the overall oxidation efficiency. Various noble metal catalysts such as Pt/C [221], PtSnRu/C [223], and PtSn/C [223] were presented to lead the EOR-HWE systems in acidic electrolyte solutions for pure H2 generation (3H2O + C2H5OH → 12H+ + 2CO2 + 12e–). Pd NPs modified 3D structured TiO2 nanotube arrays (Pd/TNTA) with a high ECSA were fabricated to drive the EOR-HWE configuration in an alkaline solution and achieved an energy saving of 26.5 kWh kg–1, surpassing the state-of-the-art proton electrolyte membrane water electrolysis (Figs. 17(c), (c1)–(c8)) [224]. The Pd/TNTA(+,–)-based EOR/HER synergistic electrolysis configuration attained 1.0 A cm–2 with a little cell potential of 0.69 V at 80 °C (Figs. 17(d1)–(d4)). Aside from CO2 generation due to the complete oxidation of ethanol, selective oxidation reaction of ethanol molecules coupled with HER can produce green H2 and value-added acetate or even ethyl acetate. Electrospray ionization tandem mass spectrometry (ESI-MS) and 13C NMR are used to observe acetate, whereas the quantity for acetate can be measured 1H NMR spectra in the presence of an external standard (e.g., dimethyl sulfoxide). The ethyl acetate products can be detected and analyzed by gas chromatography tandem mass spectrometry (GC-MS) and 1H NMR. Inexpensive transition metal nanomaterials with rich redox reactions can serve as effective electrodes/electrocatalysts for EOR synergizing the HWE system with enhanced electrocatalytic activities. For example, electronegative F dopants in β-FeOOH (F-modified β-FeOOH) could stabilize the adsorption energy between OH– species and Fe active centers and as well as C2H5O– reactants, facilitating the establishment of high-valence Fe4+ sites due to intensive positive charge clouds across the Fe centers [116]. Consequently, the simulative two-electrode Pt/C(–)//F-modified β-FeOOH(+) electrolyzer directing the EOR/HER synergistic electrolysis in an alkaline media reached 10 mA cm−2 with a low electrolytic potential of 1.43 V. Hetero-nano-structured NiOOH-CuO anchored on 3D conductive Cu foam (NiOOH-CuO/CF) electrode was prepared via an annealing treatment and electrolytic deposition strategy (Figs. 18(a)−(c) ) [53]. Benefitting from the improved catalytic properties of active Ni and Cu species with strong synergistic coupling effect, the engineered NiOOH-CuO/CF electrode presented an enhanced EOR activity under alkaline conditions, delivering 200 mA cm−2 at 1.347 V and acquiring a high conversion rate of ethanol into acetic acid with notable operational stability and remarkable selectivity (Figs. 18(d)−(f)). The DFT results confirmed the enhancement in the local charge density and electronic structure at heterointerfaces, allowing more suitable adsorption energy for intermediate species of EOR stages with lower reaction barriers (Figs. 18(g)−(i)). Additionally, advanced bimetallic Cu-Ni sulfide heterojunction with multiple interfaces and many S-vacancies loaded on graphene frameworks (Cu1Ni2-S/G) as a highly active bifunctional electrocatalyst for catalyzing ethanol molecules was constructed via a typical hydrothermal approach and calcination process (Figs. 18(j)−(k) and (k1)−(k4)) [225]. Through the S-vacancies and heterointerface engineering, the as-obtained Cu1Ni2-S/G nanocomposite displayed an enhanced electrocatalytic performance with a relatively low overpotential, remarkable selectivity, and robust long-term durability. The optimized Cu1Ni2-S/G//Cu1Ni2-N electrolyzer device-mediated electro-coupled EOR/HER synergistic processes in the HWE system acquired 10 mA cm−2 at an ultra-low cell voltage of 1.37 V in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH solution containing 1.0 mol L−1 C2H5OH, exceeding that of the OWS (10 mA cm−2 at 1.733 V). This implies a significant advantage of saving electricity throughout the EOR/HER co-electrolysis (Figs. 18(l)−(o)). Importantly, the DFT investigations confirmed the overall synergistic effects of advantageous compositional and structural features induced by S-vacancies and strong interfacial coupling. These features could modify the electronic configuration, favoring suitable adsorption fashion of reaction intermediates, and dramatically reduce the energy barrier of catalytic processes (Figs. 18(p)–(s)). Similar to the MOR synergizing the HWE technology, devising EOR collaborating HWE configuration suffers from problems related to electrocatalyst formulation. It was observed that anodic EOR produces various C1 and C2 products which can be accomplished through complex reaction pathways. These products vary according to the type of adopted EOR electrocatalyst. Hence, designing effective nanomaterials to generate favorable value-added species via selective electrooxidation reactions is a great challenge. 6.1.3 Benzyl alcohol (BA) electrooxidation synergizing HWE systems The selective anodic electrooxidation reaction of BA with sustainable electricity input does not need severe conditions to attain a highly selective conversion process. The corresponding oxidation products of BA (e.g., benzaldehyde and benzoic acid) are elementary building units with floppy applications in the modernistic chemical industry and the synthesis of fine chemicals. Therefore, the development of an efficient BA oxidation reaction (BAOR)/HER co-electrolysis system ensures better storage of chemical energy and utilization of sustainable electricity. During the past decade, numerous scientists have accomplished controllable modifications related to the composition, surface morphologies, and microstructures of nanomaterials-based electrode/electrocatalyst for BAOR, hence promoting the reaction kinetics and electrocatalytic activity as well as selectivity with lower voltages. For instance, You et al. [226] constructed hierarchically 3D porous Ni (hp-Ni) microspheres via an electrodeposition strategy for catalyzing the electrooxidation reactions of different organic substances (e.g., 4-nitrobenzyl alcohol, BA, ethanol, and HMF) through the HWE configuration, realizing the synergy of energy-saving H2 production and oxidative organic upgrading processes (Figs. 19(a) and (b) ). Investigating the hp-Ni electrode for the anodic oxidation reactions of the above oxidizable substrates yielded similar onset potentials, irrespective of various intrinsic oxidation thermodynamics of these reactions (Figs. 19(c) and (d)). Under ambient conditions, the assembled electrolyzer synergizing HWE system using the hp-Ni electrodes in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/10 mmol L–1 BA afforded 10 and 20 mA cm−2 at a cell voltage of 1.50 and 1.54 V, respectively, substantially lower than those of the OWS configuration. The resultant liquid products analysis obtained by the HPLC demonstrated the formation of benzoic acid with a high FE of ~97% (Figs. 19(e)–(g)). Ni(OH)2 and Co(OH)2 nanosheets were vertically grown on a 3D microporous NF current collector electrode (Ni-OH/NF and Co-OH/NF) through a fast electrodeposition approach and directly applied for the BAOR/HER synergistic electrolysis in NaOH aqueous solution [227]. The obtained Ni-OH/NF sample showed a higher electrocatalytic current density than the Co-OH/NF sample, which was largely attributed to the strong oxidizing capability of the in-situ generated high-valence NiOOH active layer. The enrollment of Ni-OH/NF as an anodic electrode and Pt mesh as a cathodic electrode in a two-electrode compartment could catalyze the electro-coupled BAOR/HER reactions through the HWE system and provide a smaller electrolytic cell potential than the OWS with enhanced selectivity (96%) and high FE (95%). With the introduction of heteroatomic N dopants, binary Ni-Mo supported on NF (N-Mo-Ni/NF) scaffold through a hydrothermal method could reveal an improved selectivity for catalyzing BA to benzoic acid [228]. Only 1.338 V was required by the electro-integrated BAOR/HER couple to gain 100 mA cm−2 in 0.1 mol L–1 BA solution, enabling about 252 mV reduction in the cell potential as compared with the conventional OWS. Besides, the selectivity of the conversion process into benzoic acid reached 98.2% with a high FE of up to 98.7%. Engineering catalytic surfaces with abundant vacancies and holes can modify the surface electronic structures and surface chemistry as well as elevate the number of active sites, hence remarkably reinforcing the catalytic activity. Controllable defect engineering ensures the manipulation of adsorption strength on exposed surfaces, which may influence the selective electrocatalytic oxidation processes and conversion reaction of reactants into targeted products. Given this, functional vacancies and holes dominated by Ni hydroxide (h-Ni(OH)2) were developed by an easy hydrothermal reaction combined with Zn etching through the Ostwald ripening process [229]. The 3D h-Ni(OH)2 nanohybrid was employed as an anode for the selective electrooxidation of BA molecules into their corresponding aldehydes or acids with a high FE. Consequently, the paired BAOR/HER synergistic electrolysis equipped with the h-Ni(OH)2 anode and PtO2/h-Ni(OH)2 cathode could obtain 10 mA cm−2 at 1.48 V. Above 92% selectivity to benzoic acid with 99% BA conversion was also realized. Theoretical characterizations emphasized that the introduced O-vacancies and dense holes contributed significantly to the adsorption properties of h-Ni(OH)2 nanohybrid for intermediates involved within the selective electrooxidation reaction. Spinel complexes with exposed bimetallic active sites deserve to be further applied for selective oxidation reactions of various organic substrates. The in-situ growth of bimetallic NiCo2O4 nanosheet frameworks on NF substrate (NiCo2O4/NF) as a self-supported electrode for efficient electrolytic oxidation of BA into benzoic acid in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH solution was realized through a low-temperature hydrothermal reaction and an annealing treatment [230]. Under optimized experimental conditions, the as-synthesized NiCo2O4/NF electrode exhibited a selectivity of 95% BA conversion into benzoic acid with excellent stability and high FE. Experimental results stated that the electrolytic BAOR/HER reaction directed by the devised NiCo2O4/NF(+,–) cell in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/50 mmol L−1 BA acquired 10 mA cm−2 at a cell voltage of 1.51 V, greatly lower than that obtained in a pure 1.0 mol L−1 KOH (10 mA cm−2 at 1.82 V). Ru-based electrocatalysts with a narrow redox potential for the Ru2+/Ru couple displayed a promise to drive the selective transformation of organic molecules with a small voltage and achieved nearly 100% FE for benzaldehyde, which is significantly crucial for minimizing the potential of anodic electrooxidation reactions synergizing HWE. Noticeably, Ru NPs anchored on N-doped CNTs (Ru-NPs@NCNTs) were synthesized to drive the BAOR/HER synergistic electrolysis with a reduced potential (Figs. 19(h)–(j)) [231]. The DFT findings displayed strong interactions between the Ru surface atoms and OH* hydroxyl group of BA, facilitating the occurrence of a horizontal adsorption geometry between the Ru-NPs@NCNTs catalyst and BA molecules. This favored the activation of OH* due to the abbreviated distance from the Ru surface reaction sites to the OH* (Figs. 19(k) and (l)). As a result, the established BAOR/HER electrolytic configuration required a working potential of 1.36 V to reach 10 mA cm−2, which was noticeably lower than that attained in the absence of BA (10 mA cm−2 at 1.83 V) (Figs. 19(m) and (n)). 6.1.4 Glycerol electrooxidation synergizing HWE systems Glycerol is a proper feedstock chemical for HWE with ultra-economic benefits and large accessibility in biodiesel synthesis. Hydrothermal and hydrogenolysis are the most common ways for the industrial oxidation of glycerol, but these methods usually require a huge energy input and an expensive infrastructure. In sharp contrast, the anodic electrooxidation reaction of glycerol produces high-purity products (e.g., formic acid, glyceric acid, lactic acid, and glycolic acid) in green and environmentally friendly tactics. Pt, Pd, Au, and their corresponding alloys are the ultimate active surfaces for the cleavage of C–C and C–O bondings, which act as the rate-determining steps for glycerol electrooxidation reaction (GOR) [232]. Under alkaline conditions, glyceric acid is largely formed on both the Pt and Au catalysts via the glyceraldehyde pathway and further oxidized to generate glycolic acid and formic acid on Au-based catalysts. The oxidation of glycerol in neutral solutions is more sluggish and glyceraldehyde is thus the major product, but only Pt catalysts reveal a suitable catalytic activity for forming glyceraldehyde and the corresponding PtO x surface oxide layer guides the subsequent conversion into formic acid and CO2, evidencing that Pt-based surfaces are catalytically active in all pH window [233]. The glycerol oxidation pathways on Pt and Au catalysts in various mediums are illustrated in Figs. 20(a)–(c) [234]. The surface morphologies, particle geometry, and high-index facet exposure of noble metal atoms can regulate their catalytic activity and selectivity for various reaction mechanisms. With an identical electrocatalytic capability to the state-of-the-art Pt and more abundant resources, Pd-based catalysts also receive intensive interest. Cornell and co-workers explored a bimetallic Pd0.9Ni0.1 catalyst via an electrodeposition technique and investigated the role of substantial factors such as OH– concentration, NaOH/glycerol ratio, electrolyte temperature, and mass transfer during anodic GOR. Under optimized reaction conditions (1.0 mol L–1 NaOH/1.0 mol L–1 glycerol, and 80 °C), the as-prepared Pd0.9Ni0.1 catalyst gained a maximum current density of 793 mA cm−2 at a working voltage of –0.125 V vs. Hg/HgO [235]. Moreover, the possible reaction mechanism of GOR for producing formate could be proposed to proceed via a successive-stepped pathway during the whole catalysis process and secondary as well as primary carbons of glycerol induced formate. In such an electrolysis step, glycerol species was electro-oxidized into glyceraldehyde and subsequently glycoladehyde and formate through the cleavage of the C–C bond of glyceraldehyde. Afterwards, the formaldehyde and formate could yielded via the oxidation cleavage of glycoladehyde. The as-formed formaldehyde performed an intermolecular Cannizzaro reaction to construct formate and methanol. Further oxidation of methanol also produced formate product [61]. Self-supported nanostructures are more appropriate for utilization in real catalysis configurations. The strengthened connection between the active components and the underlying current collector accelerates the electric connection and hinders the peel-off of active materials. From a composition aspect, regulating the composition of nanomaterials via heteroatomic doping can adjust the electronic structures and stabilize the adsorption energy of reactive species, hence greatly promoting the catalytic properties. N-doped carbon-modified 1D Ni-Mo-N arrayed nanowires loaded on NF skeleton (NC/Ni-Mo-N/NF) were designed by a hydrothermal approach and calcination treatment as a bifunctional electrode to selectively electro-oxidize glycerol into formate and simultaneously boost green H2 generation (Figs. 20(d)–(f)) [236]. By the virtue of compositional/structural advantageous and interfacial synergy effect, the resulting NC/Ni-Mo-N/NF electrode presented enhanced electrocatalytic activities for both HER and GOR. The employment of bifunctional NC/Ni-Mo-N/NF as both the anode and cathode electrodes to drive the GOR/HER synergistic electrolysis in the HWE configuration accomplished 10 mA cm−2 with a low cell voltage of 1.38 V in the presence of 0.1 mol L−1 glycerol in the reaction solution (Figs. 20(g)–(i)). The improved body construction and surface chemistry of arrayed architectures enriched the active sites. The abundant Ni/Ni-Mo-N heterointerfaces synergistically boosted the reaction kinetics for both GOR and HER processes. Moreover, Chen and co-workers demonstrated the design and investigation of porous Ni-Mo-N nanoplates on a carbon fiber cloth (Ni-Mo-N/CFC) through a hydrothermal reaction and subsequent nitridation treatment for the concurrent generation of high-purity H2 and selective oxidation reactions of glycerol to value-added formate (Figs. 20(j)–(m)). Assembling the bifunctional Ni-Mo-N/CFC heterostructures in a dual-electrode alkaline electrolyzer could achieve 10 mA cm−2 at a low cell voltage of 1.36 V, which was 260 mV lower than that approached by the OWS system (Figs. 20(n)–(q)) [61]. High entropy alloys combining multiple elements possess excellent physicochemical properties (e.g., high toughness and hardness, unique corrosion resistance, and excellent thermal stability) relative to conventional ones. The coexistence of several elements in a single-phase high entropy alloy offers an inherent synergistic effect caused by remarkable electronic configuration and severe lattice distortion. Thus, illustrating a potential application in a variety of electrocatalytic processes. Recently, Wen's group [237] fabricated CoNiCuMnMo high entropy alloy NPs on a CC piece (CoNiCuMnMo-NPs/CC) via an in-situ growth solvothermal reaction of quintuple metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) followed by a facile pyrolysis process (Figs. 21(a)–(c) ). Electrochemical studies illustrated that the CoNiCuMnMo-NPs/CC high entropy alloy electrode possessed a remarkable ability to electro-oxidize glycerol to formate with a low overpotential and a high selectivity. A hybrid alkali GOR/acid HER flow electrolytic system was constructed to verify the promising industrial prospect of high entropy alloy using the CoNiCuMnMo-NPs/CC nanocomposite as the anode and benchmarking RhIr/Ti as the cathode. The established electrocatalytic devise could reach 10 mA cm–2 at a minimum cell voltage of 0.55 V and preserve the long-term catalysis stability for 12 d at a catalytic current signal of 50 mA cm–2 (Figs. 21(d)–(f)). The system also realized high Faraday efficiencies of 99% and 92% for the cathodic H2 generation and anodic formate production, respectively. The charge transfer capability and catalytic performance of nano-structured LDHs can be further improved by adjusting the composition, engineering defects, and stabilizing the surface environment. Implanting single atomic sites across the defects enhances electron mobility and creates an orbital hybridization at the metal-carrier interfaces, forming new bonds due to interactions between the oxygen atoms of the LDHs framework and single metal atoms (M–O bond). Furthermore, the p-electron state will be tuned to boost the activation and chemisorption of reaction species, thereby minimizing the energy barrier and strengthening the catalytic activity. For example, O-vacancies dominated 2D NiCo LDH nanostructures were developed and applied as a host scaffold to capture single atomic Pt sites (Figs. 21(g)–(j)) [59]. The EXAFS spectrum observed that the oxygen atoms of the host nanomaterial interacted with the single atomic Pt to create Pt–O5 coordinations and induce robust electronic interactions with the nano-structured LDHs (Figs. 21(k) and (l)). The DFT analysis outcomes verified that the implanted Pt atomic sites abridged the p-band center and optimized the hydrogen adsorption energy as well as the HER kinetics (Fig. 21(m)). The electro-coupled GOR/HER synergistic processes in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.1 mol L–1 glycerol utilizing the self-supported PtSA-NiCo LDHs/NF electrodes attained 100 mA cm–2 at only 1.37 V and boosted the selective conversion of glycerol into formate (Figs. 21(n) and (o)). 6.1.5 Other alternative alcohols and plastic wastes electrooxidation synergizing HWE systems In addition to the above anodic electrooxidation reactions, some other alternative reactions have been recently investigated to guide high-purity H2 generation via the HWE pathway [238]. EG is the simplest part of the glycol group and serves as a proper coolant in automotive radiators. It is also applied as a reagent for the manufacture of alkyd resins, polyesters, and artificial waxes. Considering the advantage of wastes, the anodic oxidation reaction of EG by using polyethylene terephthalate (PET) plastic is proposed to fit with the electrocatalytic upcycling of PET to ware products and sustainable H2 [24–27,238]. In this context, binder-free CoNi0.2P ultra-thin nanosheets (CoNi0.2P-uNS/NF) were prepared via a handy template post-phosphorization approach (Figs. 22(a) and (b) ) [239]. Profiting from the porous nano-structured framework, expanded specific surface area, more available active sites, surface electrochemical reconstruction, and favorable electronic effect, the resulting CoNi0.2P-uNS/NF electrode showed a prominent electrocatalytic activity for HER and EG oxidation reaction (EGOR) in an alkaline electrolyte (Figs. 22(c) and (d)). To further expand the territory for the co-generation of H2 and value-added species, a two-electrode electrolyzer configuration supported with the CoNi0.2P-uNS/NF electrodes was constructed to drive the EGOR/HER synergistic electrolysis in a 1.0 mol L–1 KOH. The integrated CoNi0.2P-uNS/NF//CoNi0.2P-uNS/NF system could convert the mixture of terephthalate and EG into formate at the anode and generate H2 at the cathode compartment. Moreover, a current of 50 mA cm−2 was afforded with a lower integral electrolytic potential of 1.24 V than the OWS (1.53 V) (Figs. 22(e) and (f)). Additionally, Chen and co-workers demonstrated the synthesis of Ni3N-Ni0.2Mo0.8N nanowire array heterostructures on a CC scaffold (Ni3N-Ni0.2Mo0.8N/CC) through solvothermal reaction and annealing treatment (Figs. 22(g)–(i)) for simultaneous electrolytic HER and glycerol conversion into formate with an exceptional FE of 96% [240]. With the electrode serving as both the anode and cathode, the resulting alkaline Ni3N-Ni0.2Mo0.8N/CC(+,–) electrolyzer driving the GOR/HER couple in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.1 mol L–1 glycerol revealed a cell voltage of only 1.40 V to present 10 mA cm−2 (Figs. 22(j)–(l)). Side-by-side, the electrode could also catalyze the conversion of EG from PET plastic into formate. The analyzed DFT calculation findings elucidated that the engineered heterojunctions provided more appropriate adsorption energies for water, H*, and glycerol, meanwhile the interfacial electronic redistribution at heterojunction regions with a dense hole on Ni0.2Mo0.8N and electron accumulation on Ni3N favored fast electron transfer rate during electrocatalytic step, thus boosting the overall electrocatalytic efficiency toward both EGOR and HER (Figs. 22(m) and (o)). Shi's group reported the selective electrocatalytic formation of value-added glycolic acid during the anodic EGOR process accompanied by the concurrent H2 generation at the cathode under alkaline conditions over the PdAg electrocatalyst anchored on a 3D NF substrate (PdAg/NF) [241]. Resultantly, the PdAg/NF electrode displayed a high catalytic activity for EGOR and obtained 10 mA cm−2 at a low voltage of 0.57 V under the three-electrode cell setup, which was markedly less than that of the OER (0.98 V) in the same reaction solution. Furthermore, assembling the PdAg/NF anode and Pt plate cathode in a dual electrolytic system could facilitate the generation of high-purity H2 gas through the coupled EGOR/HER synergistic electrolysis with a high FE of ≍ 100%. Such an electrolyzer delivered 20 mA cm−2 at a cell potential of 1.02 V in 0.5 mol L−1 KOH/1.0 mol L−1 EG electrolyte solution. Isopropanol or isopropyl alcohol provides a hydrogen capability of 3.3 mass% with an energy storage density of 1.11 kWh kg−1 based on the minimum heating point of chemically bound hydrogen. As a liquid organic hydrogen carrier, isopropanol is a very attractive substance for power-dense conversion in direct fuel cell and mobile device applications. The electrode reactions of a direct isopropanol fuel cell include the anodic electrooxidation of isopropanol to acetone as expressed below [242]: (30) CHOH(CH3)2 → 2H+ + CO(CH3)2 + 2e– Given the advantages above, the anodic oxidation of isopropanol molecules through the HWE system was explored to effectively decrease the overall potential of electrolysis and acquire the co-production of H2 and fine chemicals. For example, 2D ultra-thin Rh nanosheets (Rh-NSs) with an atomic thickness were prepared via an easy cyanogel-reduction route and illustrated a high electrolytic activity for catalyzing HER and thermodynamically favorable isopropanol oxidation reaction (IOR) with a remarkable selectivity in an alkaline solution [243]. An alkaline membrane-free electrolyzer supported with the bifunctional Rh-NSs nanostructures modified indium-tin oxide glass substrate showed a good ability to direct the IOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, producing persistent as well as stable H2 gas bubbles with an operational potential of only 0.4 V. Specifically, the constructed Rh-NSs(+,–) electrolytic system exhibited an impressive electrocatalysis activity and reached 10 mA cm−2 at a very small potential of 233 mV. Meanwhile, the generation of valuable acetone was also observed at the anode compartment without CO2 gas bubbles. Optimizing of morphology and structure of Pd-based compounds can not only expose most of the surface atoms to serve as catalytically active centers but also ensure unique surface structural effects and elastic electron mobility. Anisotropic growth of metal nanocrystals into atomically defect-rich metallene surfaces can modify the interatomic structure, expose more active sites, and induce greater atomic utilization. Very recently, Wang et al. [244] developed atomically thin, defect-rich PdIr bimetallene nanoribbons (PdIr BNRs) via a wet chemical route as an efficient electrocatalyst for isopropanol-assisted H2 production in seawater. On the one hand, the atomic-level thickness and abundant structural defects with low coordination numbers of PdIr BNRs maximized the exposure of atoms and provided more accessible active sites to smarten the charge and mass penetration paths (Figs. 23(a)–(e) ). The PDOS calculations illustrated that the d-band center of PdIr BNRs was notably shifted downward compared with that of Pd, verifying that the incorporated Ir regulated the electronic structures of Pd and shifted the d-band center downward, thus optimizing the surface microenvironment of IOR and HER catalytic processes. Taking these geometric and electronic structure advantages, the PdIr BNRs(+,–)-based two electrode electrolyzer could catalyze the combined IOR/HER synergistic couple in a hybrid seawater electrolysis system, accomplishing 10 mA cm−2 at a low cell voltage of 0.38 V (Figs. 23(f)–(i)). Such an alkaline co-electrolysis system not only guided the formation of clean H2 gas but also facilitated the production of high-value-added acetone with high selectivity. Therefore, preventing the accumulation of carbonate on exposed surfaces and optimizing the adsorption of reactants and intermediates. Cyclohexanone (CHO) is a chemical intermediate used in the industrial synthesis of caprolactam and adipic acid, which are usually used for manufacturing nylon-6, nylon-66, plastics, and chemical fiber. The formation of CHO is performed through cyclohexanol dehydrogenation, while the high endothermic reaction and thermodynamic equilibrium are the main obstacles due to the deactivation of catalytic surfaces by carbonaceous species assemblage. Thus, frequent regeneration is a requisite. Accordingly, bifunctional Co2(OH)3Cl/FeOOH@NF nanosheet architectures were fabricated via a straightforward impregnation method to drive the co-generation of high-purity H2 and value-added product during the anodic cyclohexanone oxidation reaction [245]. The synergistic effect between Co2(OH)3Cl and FeOOH components boosted the electrooxidation of cyclohexanol and accelerated the reaction rate by modulating the charge transfer kinetics. The constructed Co2(OH)3Cl/FeOOH@NF(+,–)-based two-electrode cell through the HWE configuration needed only a cell potential as low as 1.46 V to reach 10 mA cm−2 in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/2 mmol L−1 cyclohexanol. 6.2 Aldehyde synergizing HWE systems Currently, aldehydes such as HMF and FF are used as easily oxidizable carriers to boost high-purity H2 production in the HWE system and induce the synchronous production of value-added chemicals (e.g., FDCA and FA) due to their unique kinetics and thermodynamic properties [143]. As a potential alternative to terephthalic acid, FDCA shows high importance as a raw material for fabricating polymeric materials, whereas FA is used for flavors, pharmaceutical, and fragrance industries. Conventional thermochemic oxidation of HMF and FF can be facilitated through the employment of precious metal catalysts under severe conditions (elevated temperature, large oxygen pressure, strong basicity, and expensive/toxic reagents). In contrast, anodic electrooxidation of these molecules is performed in neat pure water/seawater under ambient conditions without additional solvents or chemical agents at a proper selectivity to the targeted chemicals and a high transformation rate using advanced bifunctional noble metal-free electrodes/electrocatalysts (Table 3 ). 6.2.1 HMF electrooxidation synergizing HWE systems HMF is a desirable biomass-assisted substance since its related electrooxidation products possess axial applications in biofuels, medicines, and fine chemicals manufacturing. However, the conversion of HMF to FDCA has been extensively presented. The anodic oxidation of HMF at room temperature and atmospheric pressure is thermodynamically preferable in comparison to the classical OER process, proposing synergistic reactions to concurrently produce cost-effective and greener H2 gas. The electrocatalytic reactions of anodic HMF oxidation reaction (HMFOR) and cathodic HER as well as the HMFOR/HER couple in HWE configuration can be described in the following Eqs. (31)−(33): (31) HMFOR at the anode: 6OH– + HMF → 4H2O + 6e– + FDCA (32) HER at the cathode: 6e– + 6H2O → 6OH– + 3H2 Overall HMF/HER couple electrolysis: (33) H2O + HMF → 3H2 + FDCA Considering the increasing cost and partially improper electrocatalytic characteristics of precious metal electrocatalysts for electrooxidation of HMF, transition metal-based bifunctional electrodes/electrocatalysts have attracted much research interest [246]. In particular, Ni-based nanomaterials present noticeably high electrocatalytic activities. For instance, a hierarchically porous Ni3 S2/NF electrode was synthesized via a one-pot sulfurization process to electro-catalyze the anodic oxidation reactions of five representative organic substrates (HMF, BA, ethanol, furfuryl alcohols, and FF) with excellent Faradaic efficiencies close to 100% [247]. All five anodic oxidation reactions revealed much lower overpotentials than that of the commonplace OER process. In particular, coupling the HMFOR with HER in the HWE system enabled a more valuable FDCA product at the anode and an appealing H2 evolution at the cathode. Moreover, the cell potential of the constructed Ni3 S2/NF(+,–) cell-based O2 free electrolyzer could sustain a benchmarking catalytic current of 100 mA cm–2 with 200 mV potential reduction relative to that of sole water electrolysis configuration (Figs. 23(j)–(l)). 3D Ni2P NPs on NF (Ni2P NPA/NF) backbone as a model electrode were readily engineered via a straightforward phosphorization process, in which the commercially available NF piece acted as the Ni source [248]. The bifunctional electrode could catalyze the electro-coupled HMFOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, boost the conversion of HMF to FDCA, and generate H2 altogether under ambient conditions. The as-fabricated Ni2P NPA/NF(+,–) two-electrode electrolyzer catalyzing the HMFOR/HER synergistic processes through an alkaline HWE system supplied a catalytic current of 10 and 50 mA cm−2 with a potential of 1.44 and 1.58 V, respectively in the presence of 10 mmol L−1 HMF in the reaction solution compared with 1.65 and 1.80 V for the OWS. Besides, close unity Faradaic efficiencies were realized for both the FDCA (98%) and H2 (100%) co-production together with excellent stability (Figs. 23(m)−(o)). Nano-structured LDHs-based electrocatalysts are competent to boost the HMF electrooxidation because these transition metal nano-compounds are thermodynamically shaky and can be readily converted into catalytically active oxyhydroxides in highly oxidative solutions. Luo et al. [249] reported Cu sulfide@NiCo-LDHs (CuxS@NiCo-LDHs) core-shell nanoarrays via chemical oxidation growth route-ion exchange reaction-electrodeposition strategy to further increase the active site exposure (higher ratio of Ni3+/Ni2+ after introducing Co into the layered hydroxide), improve the surface electronic structures and mass transfer kinetics throughout the open nanostructure (Figs. 24(a)–(d) ). Theoretical investigations confirmed the role of incorporating Co sites in regulating the electronic states of NiCo-LDHs compared with the pure NiOOH. Additionally, the XPS spectra showed a higher Ni3+/Ni2+ ratio after inserting Co into the layered hydroxide structure (Figs. 24(e)–(g)). Thus, the Ni centers of mixed LDHs served as the dominant catalytic sites whereas the Co species contributed to the electronic configuration amendment, facilitated the oxidation of Ni(OH)2 to active NiOOH center, and accelerated the adsorption of HMF. As an efficient bifunctional electrode, optimized Cu x S@Ni0.75Co0.25-O m H n hetero-nanostructures delivered superior electrocatalytic performances toward both HER (10 mA cm− 2 at 107 mV) and HMFOR (87 mA cm− 2 at 1.3 V) under a half-cell electrolytic design with persistent catalysis durability and high FE for the FDCA and H2 co-generation close to unity. The Cu x S@Ni0.75Co0.25-O m H n (+,–)-based electrolyzer driving the HMFOR/HER synergistic electrolysis approached 10 mA cm− 2 at 1.34 V, promoting both biomass upgrading and simultaneous H2 generation with less energy consumption (Figs. 24(h) and (i)). Motivated by the growing focus on Co-based bifunctional electrocatalysts toward HER/OER processes, some studies have also elucidated their activity for simultaneous oxidation of HMF into FDCA and production of high-purity H2 through a hybrid strategy. Along with this, pine needles-shaped Co3O4 nanostructures were grown on NF (CoNW/NF) skeleton via a simple hydrothermal reaction and subsequent low-temperature pyrolysis route. The binder-free nanostructures were applied for HMFOR and HER electrocatalysis in a 1.0 mol L–1 KOH electrolyte with a complete HMF conversion and large H2 evolution [250]. Integrating both HMFOR and HER synergistic electrolysis in the HWE system for simultaneous co-generation of H2 gas and FDCA value-added product presented a promising electrocatalytic capability and robust electrochemical stability performance with a high FE of ≍ 100%. Such a hybrid electrolysis system obtained 10 mA cm−2 at 1.504 V, unambiguously proving the concept of energy barrier rebate by replacing the OER with HMFOR. Electrodeposited Co-P film with enhanced electrocatalytic activity for oxidative upgrading of HMF to FDCA and catalysis of HER in an alkaline media was also explored [251]. Upon serving as an electrode for catalyzing the HMFOR in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/50 mmol L–1 HMF, 20 mA cm−2 catalytic current density was achieved with an overpotential of 1.38 V vs. RHE before the takeoff of competing OER. Long-term chronoamperometric signal illustrated about 100% conversion efficiency of HMF with ~90% yield of FDCA. Additionally, the Co-P(+,–) electrolyzer cell directing electro-combined HMFOR/HER synergistic processes in the HWE setup needed 1.44 V to sustain 20 mA cm−2, revealing 150 mV reduction in cell potential relative to that of the OWS with almost a unity FE for H2 evolution. To further enhance the activity of MoS2-based bifunctional electrocatalysts for catalyzing the HMF/HER couple, a contributory cocatalyst with optimized chemisorption and activation of O-containing intermediates must be incorporated. On one hand, engineering unexpected electronic interactions and exposing more reactive sites by creating more heterointerfaces is greatly desirable. For example, 3D porous heterostructured Ni3 S2-MoS2 nano-flowers supported on NF (Ni3 S2-MoS2/NF) electrode with strong electronic interactions between the Mo, Ni, and S components and caused by the electron accumulation across the Mo and S atoms and dense positive charge on Ni [252]. The enhancement in electrocatalytic efficiency of bifunctional Ni3 S2-MoS2/NF electrode for both HMFOR and HER was mainly related to the synergism between Ni3 S2 and MoS2, strategic heterogeneous interfaces, abundance of exposed reactive sites, and sturdy electronic interactions. An electrolyzer-based Ni3 S2-MoS2/NF(+,–) assembly could drive the HMFOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, requiring a cell voltage of 1.44 and 1.53 V to sustain 10 and 50 mA cm–2, respectively, which was much less than that of the OWS. Impressively, such a dual-electrode configuration required only 1.40 V to operate a solar cell. Analyzed theoretical results displayed that the engineered NiO-MoS2 heterojunction could extremely boost the adsorption capabilities for the HMF and H*, providing a high catalysis efficiency for HMF molecules. The ameliorated chemisorption and activation of O-containing high-valence Ni intermediates expedited the water decomposition, hence boosting the HER activity. In addition, several mono-/multi-component nanomaterials were also investigated for catalyzing the electro-merged HMFOR/HER synergistic electrolysis such as CoNiP nanosheet integrated electrode [253], Mo-doped Ni0.85 Se [254], N-doped MoO2 with Ni3S2 [255], Co-Ni x P@C [256], heterostructured Ni3N-NiMoN nanowires [257], Co3O4 [258], MoO2-FeP@C [135], CoP-Cu3P/CC [259], Ni/Ni0.2Mo0.8N/NF [260], and Ni3N-V2O3 [261]. 6.2.2 FF electrooxidation synergizing HWE systems FF is a multi-functional chemical compound and biomass intermediate derived in large quantities from lignocellulosic as a raw material with many commercial uses such as food flavoring, personal care products, and biofuels. It has a distinct molecular structure and can be transformed into C4 and C5 hydrocarbons, in which C4 chemicals are produced via selective oxidation while C5 chemicals are formed through selective hydrogenation and/or hydrogenolysis. Under the economy circle concept, investigating the anodic FF oxidation reaction (FFOR) to reduce the high energy consumption, and facilitate the formation of valued chemicals containing oxygen atoms as well as sustainable H2 production is of huge significance. 3D interconnected hollow PdCu alloy networks (H-PdCu ANs) were synthesized through the Kirkendall effect via a direct reduction of transition metal cyanogel [262]. The bifunctional electrocatalytic activity of H-PdCu ANs was featured as a benchmarking model electrocatalyst for FFOR with an ultra-low onset potential (0. 1 vs. RHE). The H-PdCu ANs catalyst boosted the hydrogen atom release from aldehyde groups, ultimately harvesting H2 gas. Superfine assembly of anodic FFOR and cathodic oxygen reduction reaction-electrocatalytic system using bifunctional H-PdCu ANs electrocatalyst yielded a large H2 generation rate (5 mmol L−1 A−1 g−1 h−1), suitable electricity output (16.2 mW cm−2), overthrowing the conventional H2 evolution pathway with large electricity input. Prussian blue analogue induced the deposition of Ni2[Fe(CN)6] on underlying NF substrate via a simple chemistry method to tailor NiFe/Ni electrocatalyst with a desirable electrocatalytic activity for driving the anodic oxidation of FF and photo-directed HER catalysis through the HWE cell [263]. The in-situ powder XRD and in-situ Raman spectra manifested that the NiFe/Ni nanohybrid underwent an electrochemical reconstruction process, in which the polarons in Ni2 [Fe(CN)6] could be converted into O-vacancies, establishing a high-valence NiOOH layer. Side-by-side, the corresponding surface morphologies were also changed from nanocubes to hollow cubes, maximizing the surface area and mass transfer. Therefore, the resultant O-vacancies-rich NiOOH (v-NiOOH) afforded preferential adsorption properties for FF molecules and enhanced the reaction kinetics. The photo-electrochemical electrolyzer cell assembled with the NiFe/Ni anode and Ni-TCPP/TiO2 photo-cathode could photo-catalyze the FFOR/HER couple with small input power and high conversion as well as maximum selectivity. Furthermore, Ni2P nanoarrays on a porous NF backbone (Ni2P/Ni/NF) were developed as an efficient electrode for synergistic electrocatalysis of FFOR/HER couple in an alkaline medium [264]. Serving as the anode and cathode electrode, the as-integrated Ni2P/Ni/NF(+,–) electrolyzer device mastering the FFOR/HER synergistic electrolysis illustrated high reactivity, strong robustness, and almost unity Faradaic efficiencies for the FF conversion into FA and suitable H2 generation in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/30 mmol L−1 FF. A 100 mV reduction in the working potential was achieved to sponsor 10 mA cm–2 relative to the OWS. Liu et al. [265] designed self-supported NiMo nanostructures via a solvothermal approach and an annealing treatment under the H2/Ar atmosphere. The as-grown NiMo catalytic film was subjected to profitable structural transformation during oxidation reactions of FF. The Mo component was oxidatively leached out, enlarging the ECSA and exposing more high-valence Ni3+ catalytic sites. This boosted the catalytic performance toward FFOR with a smaller onset potential. The NiMo was proven to act as a multi-function electrode by effectively boosting the FFOR/HER synergistic electrolysis with a suitable energy conversion efficiency. Consequently, the NiMo(+,–)-based two-electrode cell afforded 20 mA cm–2 with a potential of 1.73 V, lower than that yielded in the absence of FF (1.94 V). The Faradaic efficiencies of H2 gas release and FA formation were as high as 100% and 92%, respectively. 6.3 Glucose synergizing HWE systems Glucose is an earth-abundant biomass. Anodic electrooxidation of glucose or biomass can create value-added chemicals/products such as gluconic acid, glucaric acid, gluconolactone, and gluconate (Table 2). Under mild conditions, electrocatalytic glucose oxidation reaction (GcOR) enables the formation of highly selective glucaric acid and gluconic acid, while the generation of other chemicals may be restrained by controlling the electrode/electrocatalyst potential. Glucaric acid is the greatest value-added chemical produced from biomass and can be used as a key intermediate for fabricating metal complexing agents, biodegradable detergents, and polymers. At present, glucaric acid is usually obtained by microbial fermentation or chemical oxidation method, however, the low product selectivity and purity are the main drawbacks of these techniques [101]. As far as we know, the real catalytic reactive phase for GcOR is identified as the metal oxidized centers. The GcOR process involves two catalytic paths: (1) oxidation of glucose to gluconic acid via two electrons loss and (2) conversion of gluconic acid into glucaric acid via four equivalent electrons pathways as shown in Fig. 25(a) [92].
