Various GcOR-coupled HER were designed to gain large-scale H2 generation through the HWE configuration (Table 2). For example, Liu et al. [92] synthesized 3D architectures of hydrotalcite-like NiFe LDH nanosheet arrays precursor on the surface of a commercially available NF substrate through a hydrothermal approach. Subsequently, the deposited film was annealed in an NH3 flow to attain NiFe nitrides (NiFeN x -NF) or in the air to construct NiFe oxides (NiFeO x -NF). The binder-free NiFeO x and NiFeN x electrodes demonstrated high electrocatalytic performances toward the HER and GcOR in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte solution. Specifically, the NiFeN x -NF electrode exhibited a higher yield for the HER with a smaller overpotential of 40.6 mV at 10 mA cm−2, suggesting a faster electron transfer rate during the catalysis process. Besides, the NiFeO x -NF electrode with a large ECSA revealed an exceptional activity to convert glucose molecules into glucaric acid, earning 87.6 mA cm−2 at 1.30 V with a high FE (87%). In light of this, the as-designed two-electrode cell integrating NiFeO x -NF anode and NiFeN x -NF cathode could drive the electro-merged GcOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, realizing 200 mA cm−2 at 1.48 V (Figs. 25(b)–(e)). After 24 h of sequential electrolysis at a cell voltage of 1.4 V, about 21.3% of glucose molecules were transformed into value-added glucaric acid and gluconic acid species meanwhile affording H2 gas as the product stream. Multivalent metals are always subjected to in-situ oxidation during electrochemical reactions. Such electrooxidation ofmetals offers an alternative anodic electrolytic process instead of the competing OER process for sustainable H2 production [266,267]. This can efficiently reduce the electric energy consumption. Alongside this, the electricity consumption of H2 production-coupled metal electrooxidation in the HWE system is expected to be diminished remarkably by selecting a proper metal electrode with a narrow onset potential. Inserting extra reducible agents that are qualified to reduce high-valence components into low-valent counterparts instantly can accomplish the redox cycle and control the metal electrooxidation-coupled H2 production system continuously. Cu(I)/Cu(II) redox-coupled GcOR/HER reactions in the HWE system were elaborately studied via electrooxidation of Cu2O. Glucose molecules served as low-cost biomass to efficiently generate value-added species with a highly desirable yield and facilitate the liberation of eco-friendly H2 gas through the HWE system. Additionally, appending glucose to the HWE configuration as a reducible sacrificial agent promoted the electrooxidation of metal, thus enhancing the electrocatalytic performance. The DFT calculation analyses certified that the as-formed Cu(OH)2 was promptly reduced into Cu2O via a thermocatalysis process after inserting glucose into an alkaline electrolyte solution, therefore fulfilling the Cu(I)/Cu(II) redox cycle with a low onset potential. The HR-TEM observations presented evident lattice fringes corresponding to the (111) plane of Cu2O while the morphologies evolved from their original nanoarrays to irregular structures with a relatively rough surface (Figs. 25(f)–(h)). The ex-situ XPS and in-situ Raman spectroscopy analyses jointly revealed the existence of Cu2O instead of Cu(OH)2 phase during anodic GcOR (Figs. 25(i)–(l)). Thanks to the low oxidation potential of Cu2O, the flow cell electrolyzer based-anodic Cu(OH)2 (+)||cathodic Pt/C(−) catalysts could electro-catalyze the combined GcOR/HER synergistic electrolysis in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.1 mol L–1 glucose, achieving 100 mA cm−2 with a potential input of ds0.92 V. As a result, the electricity consumption of this HWE system was 2.2 kWh per liberated cubic H2 gas, only half of the amount for pure water catalysis, proposing an effective generation of high-purity H2 with a 100% FE (Figs. 25(m) and (n)). It is noteworthy that combining semiconductors and metals to establish Mott-Schottky composite nanomaterials can promote the activity, stability, and selectivity of various chemical reactions. Interestingly enough, electrons can move spontaneously across the semiconductor/metal heterojunctions, leading to eminent changes in energy band and electronic structure near heterointerfaces. Such interface optimization continuously modifies the work function of the Schottky barrier, thereby re-adjusting the electron cloud density on active centers and inducing the accumulation of negative charges on one component with a greater work function. Correspondingly, hierarchical Mott-Schottky bead string nanostructures containing a Mott-Schottky heterointerface-shaped commercial CNTs as conductive kernels in-situ coupled with 3D ZIF-67-derived Co/CoP core-corona clusters (CNTs@Co/CoP) were fabricated by using a coprecipitation route at room temperature and a partial phosphorization process [268]. The Mott-Schottky effect across the Co/CoP heterojunctions not only provided more available active sites and modulated the electron donation capability, but also reinforced the charge redistribution at heterointerfaces and facilitated the electrooxidation of glucose molecules because of the equilibrium between the n-type semiconductor CoP with a low Fermi level and Co metal with a high Fermi level. The synergy between the Co/CoP and CNTs regulated the intrinsic activity of catalytic sites. Consequently, the energy barrier of the GcOR process at Co/CoP heterojunctions was decreased. The as-devised CNTs@Co/CoP(+,–) cell could direct the GcOR/HER co-electrolysis, exhibiting a minimum cell voltage of 1.42 V to reach 10 mA cm−2, much less than that of the traditional OWS (10 mA cm−2 at 1.74 V). The electro-coupled synergistic reactions boosted the co-generation of high-value-added species (e.g., glucuronic acid, gluconic acid, and gluconolactone) and intermediates as well as high-purity H2 emancipation simultaneously. 3D porous Co-Ni alloy with abundant macro/mesopores could serve as a bifunctional electrode for catalyzing both GcOR and HER processes [269]. The electro-merged GcOR/HER co-electrolysis employing the Co0.5Ni0.5/CC electrodes as both anode and cathode illustrated a low cell voltage of 1.39 and 1.52 V to reach 10 and 50 mA cm−2, respectively in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.1 mol L–1 glucose. A nanocomposite of Co NPs stabilized on N-doped porous carbon (Co@NPC) as an electrocatalyst for promoting green H2 production and mutation of glucose into valuable products was demonstrated with proper electrocatalytic behavior (Fig. 25(o)) [270]. The resulting Co@NPC-800 hybrid catalyst with integral hierarchical architectures and highly crosslinked nanoclusters revealed an enhanced electrocatalytic activity for HER in 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4 (overpotential of 215 mV at 10 mA cm−2) and GcOR in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0. 1 mol L–1 glucose (overpotential of 1.46 V to reach 10 mA cm−2) (Figs. 25(p) and (r)). The DFT findings indicated the synergism between NPC and Co, thus boosting the electrocatalytic behavior for both GcOR and HER. The incorporated N heteroatoms could synergistically modulate the adsorption strength of water molecules on the Co@NPC hybrid to accelerate the HER kinetics, while the graphitic-N-Co coordinations could adjust the glucose adsorption and improve the corresponding GcOR reactivity (Figs. 25(s) and (t)). The Co@NPC-800(+,–)-based electrolytic cell could accelerate the GcOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, approaching 10 mA cm−2 with a potential of 1.56 V which was 180 mV lower than that of the OWS. More importantly, the glucose oxidation by this system boosted the H2 production at the cathode side with a high FE of up to 98.9% (Figs. 25(u) and (v)). Besides, the electrooxidation transformation of glucose molecules to valuable-added chemicals such as lactic acid and formic acid together with a few contents of gluconic acid and glucaric acid was also detected, which significantly decreased the energy consumption. So far, a large range of electrodes/electrocatalysts such as Fe0.1-CoSe2/CC [271], Co-doped α-Ni(OH)2 [272], Fe2P/stainless steel mesh [273], Ru@Ni-B/NF [274], CoOOH [74], and commercial cobalt–nickel foam [275], were synthesized and applied for boosting the GcOR/HER synergistic electrolysis through the HWE configuration. 6.4 Hydrazine synergizing HWE systems N2H4 is a significant chemical with vast applications in direct fuel cells, rocket fuels, pharmaceutical products, agricultural chemical compounds, and chemical industries [276,277]. However, the emission of N2H4 causes serious human damage and environmental pollution due to its strong toxicity and corrosion properties. Bearing in mind the tremendously low theoretical thermodynamic electrooxidation potential of N2H4 (−0.33 vs. RHE), investigating HzOR to support effective H2 release through the HWE system has come into the spotlight [278]. Hence, merging HzOR with HER not only excessively minimizes the cost-effectiveness of H2 release, but also brings great benefits concerning environmental sustainability. On the one hand, anodic HzOR as a four-electron transfer process is more favorable than other organic substrates. While highly efficient, cost-effective, and earth-abundant nano-electrodes/ nano-catalysts are still eligible to further accelerate the H2 generation through HzOR synergizing HWE systems with large current densities. Compared with other hydrogen carriers, N2H4 possesses conspicuous advantages: (1) it has no carbon atoms and hence avoids the generation of greenhouse gases such as CO2 and catalyst-poisoning species (CO) during N2H4 electrooxidation reaction. Only water and N2 gas result from the electrolytic oxidation process of N2H4. (2) The excellent reducing property and rapid oxidation kinetics of N2H4 offer significantly reduced oxidation voltage. (3) It has a high power density. The electro-coupled HzOR/HER reactions in the HWE system can be illustrated as follows: (34) At the anode side: 4OH– + N2H4 → N2 + 4H2O + 4e– (35) At the cathode side: 4e– + 4H2O → 2H2 + 4OH– (36) Overall reaction: N2H4 → N2 + 2H2 HzOR takes place via a four-electron transfer pathway, yielding only N2 and water at the anode without poisoning species or toxic products (Eq. (34)). Another pathway can be proposed (Eqs. (37)−(40)) instead of four-step electron transfer step. (37) OH– + N2H4 → H2O + N2H3* + e– (38) OH– + N2H3* → H2O + N2H2* + e– (39) OH– + N2H2* → H2O + N2H* + e– (40) OH– + N2H* → H2O + N2 + e– Besides, a rapid two-step HzOR mechanism was recently proposed on double-hierarchical Cu doped Ni cubic nanopore. As illustrated, diazene intermediate was formed through a slow two-electron transfer step (Eq. (41)) while N2 could be released via a fast two-electron transfer (Eq. (42)) [98]. (41) 2OH– + N2H4 + NiCu* → H2O + NiCu-N2H2* + 2e– (42) 2OH– + NiCu-N2H2* → 2H2O + NiCu* + N2 + 2e– Sun's group fabricated Fe-doped CoS2 nanosheets via a hydrothermal reaction and a sulfurization process, acquiring a narrow potential of 129 mV vs. RHE to gain 100 mA cm−2 for catalyzing HzOR (Figs. 26(a)–(d) ) [118]. The electrocatalyst presented also an enhanced HER activity with an ultra-small overpotential of 40 mV to deliver 10 mA cm−2. The assembled Fe-doped CoS2 (+,–)-based electrolyzer leading the HzOR/HER synergistic electrolysis in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/0. 1 mol L−1 N2H4 electrolyte solution required a cell potential of only 0.95 V to realize 500 mA cm−2 with an appreciable H2 at the cathode and N2 bubbles at the anode. In sharp contrast to this, the OWS configuration delivered 500 mA cm−2 at a cell potential of 3.30 V. Side-by-side, the self-powered H2 production device combining both HWE and direct hydrazine fuel cell using N2H4 as the fuel and target, respectively produced pure H2 with a rate of 9.95 mmol L−1 h−1, reached a FE up to 98%, and revealed enhanced stability over 20 h under ambient conditions (Figs. 26(e)−(g)). In 2016, Sun and co-authors adopted the in-situ anchored Ni2P nanoarrays on NF (Ni2P/NF) scaffold to catalyze the HzOR/HER synergistic processes in an alkaline hydrazine solution (Figs. 26(h)−(j)) [279]. The Ni2P/NF(+,–) room temperature two-electrode device directing the HzOR/HER co-electrolysis yielded 500 mA cm−2 at a cell potential of 1.0 V with superior electrochemical long-term stability and 100% FE in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/0.5 mol L−1 N2H4 (Figs. 26(k) and (l)). Interfacial engineering is a powerful direction to modulate the adsorption of reactants and intermediates as well as strengthen the electron transport/mass penetration kinetics during HzOR. Thus, Mai and co-workers rationally designed porous nanosheets-like Cu-Ni nitride (Cu1Ni2-N) with rich interfaces via a solvothermal reaction-thermal ammonolysis process [33]. As can be seen, the resulting hybrid NPs revealed a distorted lattice structure originating from the mismatch of continuous Ni3N and Cu4N components. The observed Cu, Ni, and N elements were evenly distributed throughout the nanohybrid (Figs. 26(m)−(p)). Notably, the nanocomposite showed excellent catalytic activity and superior stability performance for HzOR and HER. This might be assigned to distinctive structural and compositional characteristics such as interconnected nano-architectures with suitable porosity and large surface area, collaborative catalytic effects of Ni and Cu centers, superhydrophilic exposed surface, and disordered structures. The merged HzOR/HER co-electrolysis using a bifunctional Cu1Ni2-N electrode realized 10 mA cm−2 at a small cell potential of only 0.24 V with a negligible deactivation over 75 h of continuous operation in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.5 mol L–1 N2H4 electrolyte (Figs. 26(q)–(s)). Theoretical outcomes certified that the strongly coupled interactions between Ni3N and Cu4N components guided the charge redistribution near heterointerfaces adjusted the surface electronic configuration and induced stronger carrier density, therefore synergistically boosting the intrinsic reactivity. The DOS calculation results proposed that the downshift in the p-band center from the Fermi level after incorporating Cu4N regulated the adsorption kinetics of reaction intermediates during catalytic processes (Figs. 26(t1)−(t3)). Exposing highly porous superhydrophilic surfaces with plenteous catalytic active sites and more flexible diffusion paths for rapid penetration of ions/reactants enhances the mass transfer and gas release as well as optimizes the reaction kinetics. Hence, Sun et al. [98] reported a self-standing double hierarchical Cu-doped Ni cubic nanopore on a 3D NF (Ni(Cu) CNP/NF) electrode via an electrolytic pulse-voltammetry deposition process and a subsequent electrochemical etching reaction with benchmarking catalytic performance for both HER and HzOR in alkaline conditions (Figs. 27(a)−(d) ). Concretely, the Ni(Cu) CNP/NF electrode obtained 10 mA cm−2 with a minimum overpotential of 41 mV for HER in a 1.0 mol L−1 KOH electrolyte solution. As an anodic electrode for catalyzing the HzOR, lower operational potentials of 76 and 233 mV were required to deliver 100 and 300 mA cm−2, respectively in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/0.5 mol L−1 N2H4 solution (Figs. 27(e) and (f)). Besides, the Ni(Cu) CNPs/NF(+,–) electrolytic cell driving the HzOR/HER synergistic electrolysis in the HWE system achieved 100 mA cm−2 at a cell potential of 0.491 V, whereas an ultra-large current density of 504 mA cm−2 could be yielded at a modicum cell potential of 1.0 V (Figs. 27(g) and (h)). The hierarchically interconnected network architectures with uniform hollow cubic structures, open spaces, 50 nm pore size, enlarged ECSA, Cu dopants, and NiO/Ni heterojunctions effectively regulated the reaction kinetics and overall catalytic efficiency. Results confirmed that the HzOR catalytic process underwent two electrons loss at the initial step to form diazene as an intermediate while the final N2 product was realized after a subsequent two-electron loss. Similarly, Zhao and co-workers constructed tri-level hierarchical nanoporous frameworks composed of nanotubular crystalline Ni(Cu) alloy-coated amorphous NiFe P-derivatives on the Ni mesh (Ni(Cu)@NiFeP/NM) through a simple electrodeposition-dealloying technique [145]. The hierarchically engineered electrode displayed remarkable electrocatalytic performance for HzOR in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH, approaching 10 mA cm−2 with a potential of 6 mV. Under the HER electrolysis conditions, the binder-free Ni(Cu)@NiFeP/NM electrode attained 100 mA cm−2 with an overpotential of 110 mV. Assembling in the HzOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, the Ni(Cu)@NiFeP/NM(+,–) dual-electrode electrolyzer reactor afforded 100 mA cm−2 at a cell voltage of 0.491 V in 1.0 mol L−1 KOH/0.5 mol L−1 N2H4, far lower than that of the OWS (Figs. 27(i)−(k)). The on-off durability tests over 12 h demonstrated that the HWE configuration for electro-paired HzOR/HER electrolysis needed an almost unchanged cell potential of 0.49 V with ± 10 mV to sustain the power-on 100 mA cm−2 . The H2 and N2 gas products at the cathode and anode compartments were calculated by the GC instrument and the corresponding H2/N2 molar ratio was found to be 3.6:1 with the H2 generation FE close to 100% (Fig. 27(l)). Following that, a 3D hierarchical nanotubular Ni-Cu alloy on a macroporous NF (Ni(Cu)/NF) as a low-cost and high-efficiency HzOR electrocatalytic nanohybrid was also prepared and utilized for energy-efficient electrolytic H2 production by HzOR in place of the OER process [38]. The Ni(Cu) electrocatalytic film possessed super-enlarged electrochemical activity for enhancing the reaction kinetics and unique porous microstructure for improving H2 bubble dissipation ability and reinforcing mass movement. These structural advantages enabled a significant enhancement in catalytic performance. As a bifunctional electrode in the HWE system for driving the HzOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, the as-designed Ni(Cu)/NF(+,–) electrolyzer with high robustness in alkaline conditions yielded 100 mA cm–2 at a cell potential of 0.41 V with the H2 production FE close to 100%. Other Ni-and Co-based nano-electrodes/nano-catalysts including NiCo-MoNi4 HMNAs/NF [280], MoNi@NF [281], Co(OH)2/MoS2 nanosheet array [282], Fe/F-Ni2P@NC [283], P-CoNS@CuPD/ B-CoNS@CuPD [284], V-Ni3N NS [285], NiSe/NF [286], Ru-FeP4/NF [287], hollow CoSe2/MoSe2 nanospheres [288], S-CuNiCo LDH [289], Co x P@Co3O4 [290], Co/LaCoO x @N-C-1 [291], Ni2P-HNTs/NF [292], N-Ni1Co3Mn0.4O/NF [293], RhRu0.5 [294], Cu x Se/CF [295], a-RhPb NFs [296], etc., were also searched and displayed enhanced electrocatalytic activities, proposing various effective strategies such as heterostructure engineering, heteroatomic implanting, and defect engineering to expose abundant multi-function catalytic centers and tailor hierarchical porous 3D architectures for intensifying the HzOR catalytic activity enhancement and maximizing the H2 liberation. These studies indicate that the HzOR is an interesting half-anodic reaction in the HWE configuration and can predominantly minimize the energy consumption of green H2 generation. Even though the well-known poisoning and weak stability of N2H4, the HzOR synergizing HWE technology for clean H2 release holds potential as one of the most promising carriers among other organic/biomass substances (Table 4 ). 6.5 Urea synergizing HWE systems CO(NH2)2 is an organic compound that can be manufactured from CO2 and ammonia via an industrial production technique [19–32]. It is widely utilized in various fields such as agriculture, industry, medicine, and N-cycling to maintain sustainable environmental development. However, a large quantity of urea-rich wastewater is produced as a result of the massive urea consumption in industrial synthesis processes, nitrogen-release fertilizer, and other industrial developments. In addition, the nitrate and ammonia products resulting from urea decomposition bring serious human health and environmental problems [170]. These critical issues motivate the present exploration of more cost-effective and sustainable options for purifying urea-containing wastewater. Impressively, the urea molecules are a good hydrogen carrier and possess the advantages of high abundance, reasonable cost, safe storage, and safe transportation [19–32]. Thus, providing a potential renewable energy source to promote sustainable fuel cell technology by replacing the conventional OER at the anode side. No matter the urea exists as an energy carrier or urea-rich wastewater, the electrochemical oxidation reaction of urea molecules has drawn increasing importance from both academia and industry as compared with other approaches (e.g., photo-oxidation and biodegradation) [297]. Urea electrooxidation not only alleviates the environmental pollution associated with untreated urea-containing wastewater but also generates green H2 simultaneously. Hence, the electrochemical catalysis of urea-coupled water splitting has been considered as a more economically feasible pathway to obtain a clean H2. UOR is an anodic half-reaction that identifies the efficiency of the major urea-based functionalities (e.g., naturally abundant fuel, pollutants treatment, and hydrogen storage chemical) in alkaline, neutral, or acidic electrolytes. Similar to the case of hydrogen-related research, electrocatalysts for driving the UOR process are still a significant key for approaching an optimized performance by accelerating the reaction kinetics and reducing the potential barriers [298]. The intrinsically sluggish UOR is dominated by a six-electron transfer process. The electrochemical reaction of UOR synergizing HWE can be highlighted as [299,300]: Anodic reaction (UOR): (43) 6OH– + CO(NH2)2 → 5H2O + N2 + CO2 + 6e– (44) Cathodic reaction (HER): 6e– + 6H2O → 6OH– + 3H2 Overall reaction (UOR/HER): (45) 6H2O + CO(NH2)2 → CO2 + N2 + 3H2 The theoretical voltage for UOR (0.37 V vs. RHE) is considerably less than that of the OER catalysis, however, the occurrence of a complicated electron transfer process negatively influences the reaction kinetics. Accordingly, constructing highly active nano-compounds to greatly enhance the utilization efficiency of renewable energy is still a formidable task. Noble metal-based electrocatalysts are frequently used as benchmarks for UOR electrolysis. However, the obstacles of scarcity and expensiveness are the basic reasons for their limited contributions to the present scientific research and future practical application of urea-based systems. In these circumstances, extensive research attention has been devoted to explore non-precious transition metal-based nanomaterials, where their corresponding electrocatalytic behavior may coincide with or even exceed those of noble metal electrocatalysts. In particular, Ni-based materials (e.g., metallic Ni, Ni-based alloys, chalcogenides, oxides/hydroxides, phosphides, and nitrides) have been mostly presented with intriguing UOR performances than other transition metal compounds, in which the NiOOH layer was identified as the major electrochemical active sites [19–32]. In the alkaline medium, Ni species can be rapidly transformed into Ni(OH)2 owing to the adsorption of OH– ions, which simultaneously oxidize into NiOOH at higher potentials. Such a Ni2+/Ni3+ transition boosts the electrocatalytic oxidation efficiency of small organic molecules such as urea. Compared with acidic or neutral UOR, alkaline UOR is more significant. In the case of an acidic UOR, very few catalysts can survive in acidic conditions with higher overpotentials for long periods, which is quite identical to the problem of acidic OER. Besides, the in-situ formed fog in acidic electrolytes may corrode the electrode and reaction cell as well as contaminate the released H2 at the cathode of the urea-coupled water electro-splitting configuration [301]. On the other hand, the as-formed Cl2 (caused by oxidation of Cl–) and HClO (induced by the disproportionation of Cl2) products during the UOR process in a neutral media are harmful to humans and environmental beings. The generation of H+ during neutral UOR catalysis implies that only precious metal-based compounds can withstand long-term operation [302]. Alkaline urea electrooxidation on active NiOOH layer takes place through either direct or indirect reaction pathways [299–302]: (1) the urea molecules and OH– ions are adsorbed, respectively on various NiOOH active sites during the direct reaction mechanism. Afterwards, the NiOOH active sites with adsorbed urea species interact with the released OH– from the electrolyte, facilitating the formation of NiOOH with CO2 and N2 products. Finally, the resultant NiOOH with adsorbed CO2 reacts with either OH– on the NiOOH or OH– in the electrolyte to create new NiOOH active sites. (2) Regarding the indirect mechanism, urea molecules interact with the NiOOH active sites to form CO2 and N2 gaseous products. Meanwhile, NiOOH converts into Ni(OH)2, inducing the loss of active catalytic sites. Although, Ni(OH)2 can further react with the OH– from the electrolyte to recreate new high-valence NiOOH sites. The mechanism of CO(NH2)2 electrooxidation over Ni-based materials involves the integration of both electrochemical and chemical reactions [300]: Electrochemical process: (46) 6OH– + 6Ni(OH)2 → 6e– + 6NiOOH + 6H2O Chemical process: (47) CO(NH2)2 + 6NiOOH + H2O → N2 + 6Ni(OH)2 + CO2 In terms of the surface valence state of Ni centers, dense Ni3+ sites are always ratified to reveal high intrinsic UOR activity. [303] fabricated Ni phosphate embedded Ni12P5 nanorod core-shell on NF (Ni12P5/Ni-Pi/NF) backbone via a phosphorization process without any additional binders or ionomers (Figs. 27(m) and (o)). The bifunctional electrode yielded much greater UOR activity and reached 100 mA cm−2 with a small overpotential of 1.337 V in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.5 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2 (Figs. 27(p) and (r)). The assembled Ni12P5/Ni-Pi/NF//Ni12P5/Ni-Pi/NF urea hybrid electrolyzer could approach a practical current density of 500 mA cm−2 at a cell potential of 1.662 V (Figs. 27(s)–(u)) [303]. Hexagonal NiCo(OH)2 nanosheet networks assembled in hierarchical microspheres with rich Ni3+ species and surface functional carboxylic groups were synthesized by a solvothermal reaction and simple room-temperature transformation route using the NiCo-MOFs as a sacrificial template [304]. The XPS and in-situ Raman characterizations demonstrated the formation of surface carboxylic groups that supported the proton-coupled electron transfer process and appreciably contributed to the enhanced UOR catalytic activity. The embedded Co centers could sufficiently raise the intrinsic activity and reduce the overpotential. The Co species controlled the quantity of in-situ generated Ni3+ species, thereby maximizing the catalytic efficiency. Strain regulation is an effective tactic to regulate the surface electronic configuration, hence manipulating the binding strength with the surface-adsorbed reactants and reaction intermediates. Inducing a strain on the surface of a proper scaffold can significantly hinder the migration tendency of isolated atomic sites and optimize the surface energy, thus, ensuring a high-loading mass of implanted single atomic sites. Recently, Lee and co-workers [314] adopted a simple approach to create tensile strain on the surface of Co3O4 support via a liquid N2-quenching technique, stabilizing 200% higher loading of single atomic Rh sites (RhSA-S-Co3O4; 6.6 wt%) compared with pristine Co3O4 (Figs. 29(a)–(e) ). First-principles calculation results illustrated that the as-prepared RhSA-S-Co3O4 possessed higher migration energy barrier with a larger negative formation on the S-Co3O4 than pristine Co3O4, extremely prohibiting the agglomeration/migration of stabilized single atomic Rh sites (Fig. 29(f)). Strikingly, the RhSA-S-Co3O4 electrocatalyst presented an excellent pH-universal electrocatalytic UOR activity, providing 10 mA cm−2 with an ultra-low potential of 1.28/1.30 V vs. RHE in alkaline/acidic media (Figs. 29(g) and (h)). Theoretical analyses also illustrated that the implanted RhSA site accelerated the adsorption/activation of urea molecules and regulated the CO*/NH* key intermediates, thereby significantly minimizing the energy barrier for the rate-determining step and boosting the UOR activity with rapid kinetics and lower onset potential. The negative shift in the d-band center of RhSA-S-Co3O4 compared with that of S-Co3O4, endorsing more proper interactions with the urea molecules (Figs. 29(i)–(k)). The assembled RhSA-S-Co3O4 (+,–) electrolyzer could direct the electro-coupled UOR/HER electrolysis processes, delivering 10 mA cm−2 at 1.33 V with impressive long-term stability for 120 h in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.5 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2 (Figs. 29(l) and (m)). The coaxial nano-architectures with hierarchical electronic and ionic transport paths could offer robust interfacial interactions between the metal active centers and heteroatomic N dopants in the carbon matrix, favoring the modification of the surface electronic structure. The N-doped carbon frameworks not only acted as a conductive scaffold for stabilizing metal components and preventing them from aggregation/corrosion but also efficiently enhanced the electronic structures, boosted charge the transfer kinetics and facilitated the adsorption of intermediates. Besides, the metallic Ni further increased the conductivity and regulated the charge redistribution, inducing the in-situ formation of high-reactive NiOOH species for higher UOR performance. The electro-merged UOR/HER reactions in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.33 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2 sustained 20 mA cm−2 with only 1.5 V, much lower than that of traditional OER/HER electrolysis in a 1.0 mol L–1 KOH solution. In this regard, ZIF-67-derived CoP NPs encapsulated in P,N co-doped carbon matrix (PNC) and stabilized on P-doped carbonized wood fibers (PCWF) were obtained by a phosphorization-carbonization strategy (Figs. 30(a)–(d) ) [322]. The resultant CoP@PNC/PCWF nanocomposite could catalyze the UOR in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.5 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2 electrolyte solution with a higher activity, yielding 50 mA cm−2 with a voltage as low as 1.32 V vs. RHE and exhibited a remarkable durability for more than 72 h at 10 mA cm−2. Such a structural effect could avoid nanoparticle agglomeration while affording a large specific surface area and reaction-accessible surface, resulting in a considerable ECSA. The introduced heteroatomic P into the carbon matrix improved the electronic configuration of carbon, produced more defects, and potentially modulated the surface/interface electronic structures of CoP@PNC/PCWF nanocomposite. The formed heterogeneous interfaces induced favorable synergistic interactions between CoP and PNC, boosting the electrocatalytic activity of CoP@PNC/PCWF for UOR. Interestingly, using the CoP@PNC/PCWF and commercial Pt/C as the anode and cathode, respectively to drive the UOR-assisted energy-saving H2 generation through the HWE system achieved 50 mA cm−2 with a cell voltage of only 1.50 V (Figs. 30(e) and (f)). Engineering bifunctional nanomaterials with hierarchical architectures containing genetic amounts of highly exposed active sites is essentially captivating in various electrolytic technologies. Synergistic optimization over geometric structures can reach the ultimate goal of maximizing electrocatalytic activity and stability. 3D compounds featuring special open and hierarchical frameworks are fascinating as they are conducive to condense active site exposure and accelerate ion/charge migration along with reinforced mechanical and structural stability [323]. The P-CoNi2S4YSSs electrocatalyst displayed superior activity and stability toward HER and UOR in alkaline conditions and sustained a low potential of 0.135 and 1.306 V vs. RHE, respectively at the minimum catalytic current of 10 mA cm−2 benefiting from the advantageous characteristics of multi-element nano-integration, enriched Ni3+ sites, and modified electronic conductivity. Consequently, the assembled P-CoNi2S4YSSs//P-CoNi2S4YSSs-based dual-electrode system efficiently derived the UOR/HER synergistic electrolysis, yielding a benchmarking catalytic current density of 10 mA cm−2 at a low cell voltage of 1.402 V with good durability even after 100 h continuous operation in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.5 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2, much better than that of the OWS (10 mA cm−2 at 1.544 V) (Fig. S30(j)). The representative O-NiMoP/NF(+,–) alkaline electrolyzer directing electro-coupled UOR/HER co-electrolysis required a narrow cell potential of only 1.55 V to reach 10 mA cm−2, significantly affording 300 mV reduction in driving potential as compared with the conventional OWS system integrating the OER/HER electrolysis under the same conditions (Figs. 30(m) and (n)). Theoretical analyses-based DFT technique disclosed that the neighboring Mo, P, and O atoms adjusted the charge redistribution and regulated the electronic environment near the Ni centers throughout the O-NiMoP nanocomposite, which in turn guided the adsorption/desorption of intermediates during UOR (Fig. S30(o)). The binder-free design of nanocomposite with 3D nanostructures ensured long-term high catalytic activity and supplied large exposure of an appreciable amount of reaction-reachable sites. The collaborative effects of both CuO NWs and Ni(OH)2 further reinforce the exceptional reactivity. As a result, the obtained electrode was directly applied for UOR in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.5 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2 electrolyte solution, presenting an excellent UOR activity with a record low potential of 1.334 V vs. RHE to gain 100 mA cm−2. Additionally, the full urea electrolysis synergizing HWE configuration for energy-saving H2 production through electro-merged HER/UOR electrolysis presented 20 mA cm−2 at a small cell potential of 1.36 V (130 mV lower than that reached by the OWS) with promising to work for 150 h of continuous electrolysis. The continuous release of gas bubbles from the electrode surface was also observed. As further proof of efficient H2 production, the assembled HER/UOR electrolyzer could be operated by using a 1.5 V commercial dry battery as an energy source. As the UOR activity of noble metal-free compounds is mainly associated with the conductivity, density of active sites, and valence state of reaction-available sites, engineering alloys is also an efficient strategy to boost the UOR catalytic reactivity due to electronic and ensemble effects as well as multi-components synergistic effect. For example, single-crystalline phase high-entropy oxides-like (FeNiCoCrCu)3O4 were synthesized via a solvothermal reaction and relatively high-temperature annealing treatment using MOF as a sacrificial template to yield a large surface area with dense active sites exposure and numerous generated O-vacancies [326]. The high-entropy multi-oxides calcined at 800 °C (HEO-800) revealed an enhanced UOR activity with a low potential of 1.35 V to attain 10 mA cm−2. The corresponding two-electrode configuration utilizing the HEO-800 alloy to catalyze the electro-paired UOR/HER electrolysis acquired 10 mA cm−2 at a driving cell voltage of 1.38 V in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.33 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2, much better than the OWS (1.48 V). Moreover, lattice-disordered nanostructures not only supply rich reactive surface sites to promote peroxidation but also enrich the local high-valence metal ions as electrocatalytically active sites, ensuring better enhancements in active sites and reactivity during a prolonged operation. Lattice-disordered high-entropy FeCuCoNiZn hydroxide nanoarrays were deposited on a CC substrate (HE-LDH/CC) via a one-step hydrothermal method, which could bring catalytic ensemble effect and boost the intrinsic activity for UOR [327]. The HE-LDH/CC nano-catalyst with a larger ECSA area, disordered nanoporous structure, and enriched surface sites could effectively achieve the electrooxidation reaction of urea with a low onset potential of 1.296 V vs. RHE and small potential of only 1.326 V vs. RHE to deliver 10 mA cm−2. The peroxidation-induced activation process during long-term operation under urea electrolysis maximized the surface active species, improved the porosity, and offered more exposed active sites. Consequently, the HE-LDH/CC(+,–)-based alkaline electrolyzer for the UOR/HER electrolysis could reach 100.8 mA cm−2 with a potential of 1.7 V in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.33 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2. Charge distribution at heterointerfaces accelerates the electrooxidation and activation of small molecules like urea. Along with this, the formed heterojunctions play a role in regulating the adsorption strength of active species and reaction intermediates. In this regard, Mott-Schottky heterojunction-shaped bimetal CoMn/CoMn2O4 nanosheet heterostructures with semiconducting phases were designed through a hydrothermal-annealing procedure (Figs. 30(p)–(s)) [97]. Based on Schottky heterojunction engineering, the obtained CoMn/CoMn2O4 nanocomposite triggered a self-powered charge transport process across heterointerfaces, which manipulated the absorption of reactant molecules, reduced the reaction barriers, and simplified the breakage of chemical bonds, hence motivating the decomposition of urea. Schottky electrode building presented better metallicity, smart electron redistribution, and much larger ECSA with abundant exposed sites, which largely boosted the UOR activity (Fig. 30(t)). Pairing CoMn/CoMn2O4 electrodes to design a dual-electrode electrolyzer for the UOR/HER electrolysis obtained 10 mA cm−2 at 1.5 V in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.5 mol L–1 CO(NH2)2, much less than that of the OWS in a 1.0 mol L–1 KOH (1.64 V) (Figs. 30(u) and (v)). More importantly, the biphase features of nano-engineered heterojunctions not only harvested the characteristics of combined Co and Mn components but also induced synergistic effects for urea electrolysis. The specific 3D porous architectures with ultra-thin arrayed nanosheets and rich nanochannels could immensely favor the infiltration with electrolyte ions, accelerate the liberation of generated gases, and speed up the reaction kinetics (Fig. 30(w)). The S-vacancy within the crystalline core modified the charge transfer properties, meanwhile, the O-vacancy in the amorphous shell boosted the mass diffusion. The bilateral Fe and Cu co-doping regulated the oxidation state of neighboring Ni ions and magnified the ECSA. As an anodic electrocatalyst for UOR, the multi-component (NiFeCu)3 S2@(NiFeCu)O electrocatalyst could deliver anodic catalytic current densities of 100 and 180 mA cm−2 at potentials of 1.37 and 1.38 V vs. RHE, respectively with excellent cycle stability without potential decay even after 12 000 cycles. The typical urea electrolyzer directing the UOR/HER couple in the HWE system yielded 100 mA cm−2 at 1.72 V, enabling 220 mV reduction in cell potential as compared with the OER/HER configuration. Based on these efficient strategies, nanomaterials with optimal compositions, structures, and morphologies can be rationally engineered to establish a smart urea-collaborating HWE system for synergistic high-purity H2 production (Table 5 ). 6.6 Sulfides synergizing HWE systems S-based organic substances (e.g., sulfide) that are ultimately manufactured from classical fossil fuels combustion of chemical industries and power plants can also raise the authoritative contaminations in wastewater and the atmosphere, producing mist and acid rain. Taking into account the favorable kinetics and thermodynamics of anodic sulfide electrooxidation, sulfides synergizing HWE stands out as a decent method for the detoxification of S-containing wastewater while simultaneously realizing low-voltage H2 generation. For example, Yu et al. synthesized bimetallic CuCoN and CuCoS on a CC through a hydrothermal-nitridation strategy [329]. In-situ spectroscopic analysis illustrated that the S2− ions were gradually electro-oxidized to short-chain polysulfides (e.g., S2 2− and S4 2−) and further assembled to generate elemental sulfur (S8). These findings confirmed that the S2− as a substitute for the anodic OER can significantly imitate electron donors and direct H2 exoneration coupled with S source recovery via the HWE system [334]. The simultaneous desulfurization and H2 production were studied by the Co-Ni3 S2-2(+,–) electrolytic cell promoting the SOR/HER synergistic electrolysis in 1.0 mol L–1 NaOH and 1.0 mol L–1 NaOH/1.0 mol L–1 Na2 S electrolyte solutions. The devised system obtained 100 and 200 mA cm−2 with a voltage of 0.95 and 1.16 V, respectively, whereas the OWS configuration required 1.99 V to drive 200 mA cm−2. Binder-free N-doped CoP nanowires on a CC (CC@N-CoP) were explored as a novel electrode to achieve synergistic electrolysis for simultaneous H2 gas generation and elemental S formation. Heteroatomic N with strong electronegativity received extra electrons from the adjoining Co atoms as compared to heteroatomic P, hence modifying the electron structures of CoP [335]. Besides, the N dopants weakened the hydrogen adsorption on exposed CoP surfaces and decreased the d-band, offering free energy close to thermos-neutral states for promoting catalytic activity. An electro-integrated system comprising an electrolyzer and oxidation reactor was established to generate H2 via HER and recover the profitable S resources concurrently in 0.5 mol L–1 H2SO4 with 0.96 mol L–1 FeSO4/0.74 mol L–1 Fe3(SO4)2 electrolyte solutions. The CC@N-CoP//CC electrolytic cell boosting the SOR/HER synergistic electrolysis obtained 10 mA cm−2 with only 0.89 V, much lower than that required by the same electrolytic configuration of amalgamated OER/HER electrolysis in H2SO4 (1.91 V to drive 10 mA cm−2). Hence, acquiring 53% energy consumption saving with the Faradaic efficiencies of ≍ 95.7% and ≍ 95.1% for H2 and S generation, respectively. It is charming and economically remunerative to couple the SOR with HER in an electrolytic cell as murdering four birds with a single gallstone, including low energy input, clean H2 production, sulfation-rich wastewater purification, and valuable S recovery. Diverse economical electrodes/electrocatalysts based on transition metal compounds have been designed to illustrate an excellent performance for electrochemical production of H2 coupled with S source via electro-merged SOR/HER synergistic electrolysis such as NiSe nanowire array [336], CoP nanoarray coated Ti mesh [337], Ni-Co-S/NF [338], Co3S4 nanowires [339], CoS2@C/MXene/NF [340], Ar plasma-treated commercial carbon paper (A-CP) [341], WS2 nanosheets [342], CoFeS2 [343] NiCu-MoS2 [344] tussock-like nano-structured Co2P [345], and α-RhS2–x metallene [346]. 6.7 Amines synergizing HWE systems Anodic electrooxidation reaction of amines is also another substitutional organic oxidation process to integrate with the HER in the HWE configuration. Amines display a much lower thermodynamic potential of −0.77 V vs. RHE than aldehyde and alcohol electrooxidation reactions, manifesting a novel thermodynamic advantage before considering the characteristic kinetics. A series of attractive organic chemicals (e.g., imines, nitriles, azo complexes, and amine oxides) can be formed during the oxidation reaction of amines, which are used in agrochemical and pharmaceutical applications. The chemical decomposition of amines needs hazardous reagents, severe reaction conditions, and expensive catalysts, which are undesirable from environmental and economic points of view [347,348]. Alternatively, amine oxidation reaction (AOR) not only skips the necessary harsh conditions and toxic reagents but also presents the chance to serve as kinetically and thermodynamically more favorable anodic electrooxidation reactions. Substituting OER with the AOR is an enthralling strategy for co-producing H2 and value-added nitriles. However, only a few studies focus on this tactic, which recently earned more scientific interest and consideration. The as-formed nitriles can be probed by GC-MS in the presence of bromobenzene as an indoor standard after treatment with ethyl acetate. Given the higher price and poisoning phenomenon of Pt-based electrocatalysts, inexpensive earth-abundant transition metal nano-compounds are the most potential alternatives. Thermodynamically more favorable benzylamine electrooxidation could be catalyzed by ultra-thin Ni2P nano-meshes to replace the OER process and accelerate the cathodic liberation of H2 gas. Ni2P nanostructures with impressive structural characteristics were directly deposited on a 3D NF substrate (Ni2P UNMs/NF) through a cyanogel-NaBH4 hydrolysis route followed by a phosphorization treatment (Figs. 32(a)–(c) ) [349]. The resultant Ni2P-UNMs/NF nanohybrid electrode exhibited superior electrocatalytic activity for benzylamine oxidation reaction (BOR) and HER in alkaline conditions (Figs. 32(d)–(f)). Consequently, the Ni2P-UNMs/NF nanohybrid was directly employed as a bifunctional electrode in a cost-competitive and energy-saving co-generation system by actualizing BOR-dominating HWE system in the presence of 0.125 mol L–1 benzylamine. The corresponding Ni2P-UNMs/NF//Ni2P-UNMs/NF electrolyzer cell leading electro-coupled BOR/HER synergistic electrolysis gained 10 mA cm−2 with an electrolysis potential of 1.41 V, lower than that recorded by the OER/HER electrolysis. Thus, offering a higher energy conversion efficiency for H2 release (≍ 100% FE) and benzonitrile construction than the conventional OWS configuration (Figs. 32(g)–(i)). The lower working potential of H2 production and formation of value-added hydrophobic nitriles with high selectivity and yield (> 93%) were successfully attained by electro-oxidizing primary amines on NiSe nanorod anode (Figs. 32(j)–(l)) [350]. Non-water-soluble hydrophobic nitrile products could float onto the electrolyte surface, impeding the active sites occupation and corresponding deterioration of electrode activity, thereby promoting continuous large-scale production. Mechanistic characterizations clarified that the in-situ formed Ni2+/Ni3+ species on the electrode surface acted as the redox-active centers for facilitating the conversion of primary amines into nitriles (Fig. 32(m)). Integrating with the CoP as a cathode for HER in an electrolytic cell for catalyzing electro-coupled BOR/HER electrolysis in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/1.0 mmol L–1 benzylamine spectacularly decreased the cell working voltage (210 mV reduction relative to that of the OWS) at the benchmarking current density of 20 mA cm−2 (Fig. 32(n)). The electrocatalytic coupled reactions could fulfill the co-generation of H2 and valuable nitriles with Faradaic efficiencies of 100% and 98%, respectively, implying much better energy conversion efficiency (Fig. 32(o)). Recently, an oxidant-free environment for energy-saving H2 release and eclectic conversion of primary amines into valuable nitriles was performed with the help of bimetallic Ni/Co MOF derivative (t-Ni/Co MOF) as a high-performance electrode. The collaborative effect of Ni and Co centers boosted the primary amine electrooxidation process with a low potential of 1.30 V vs. RHE and high FE as well as selectivity. The reversible redox species of Co2+/Co3+ facilitated the electron transfer and induced the formation of high-valence Ni states, hence hastening the kinetics of amine oxidation and simultaneous H2 generation with lower power consumption in a membrane-free electrolyzer [351]. The t-Ni/Co MOF directing electro-coupled BOR/HER electrolysis in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.02 mol L–1 benzylamine could dramatically reduce the working potential for reaching 10 and 20 mA cm−2 by 275 and 284 mV, respectively as compared with those of the OWS. A bifunctional electrode-like NF-supported heteroatomic N-doped ternary NiZnCu-LDHs stabilized on reduced graphene oxide (N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO) was developed through a hydrothermal-calcination method to reduce the energy conversion efficiency [352]. The established N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO//N-NiZnCu LDH/rGO dual-electrode configuration mastering electro-coupled AmOR/HER, HzOR/HER and UOR/HER synergistic electrolysis sustained the minimum current density of 10 mA cm−2 with a cell potential of 0.489, 0.010, and 1.305 V, respectively. Furthermore, the working cell potentials at the higher current density of 50 mA cm−2 were found to be 0.769, 0.062 V, and 1.584, respectively. These observations were superior to those of the OWS electrolysis driven by the benchmarking Pt/C//IrO2 electrolytic cell. In another work, nano-structured bimetallic oxides such as NiCo, NiMo, NiFe, and NiCe were obtained by a hydrothermal approach and employed for H2 evolution through AmOR collaborating HWE configuration. Among all, bimetallic NiCo nanoneedles were observed to show a higher electrochemical performance for HER [353]. To substantiate improved electrocatalytic activity toward cost-effective H2 production through HWE in an alkaline ammonia system, bimetallic NiCo nano-structures were subjected to a nitridation process under an ammonia/Ar atmosphere at a relatively high temperature to achieve NiCo2N. The H-shaped cell with an alkaline ion exchange membrane-based two-electrode reactor investigating the NiCo2N nanocomposites certified that the coupled ammonia electrolysis was more energy efficient than OWS. The merged AmOR/HER electrolysis reached 100 mA cm−2 with a driving cell potential of 0.71 V in ammonia alkaline electrolyte. Dihydroisoquinolines with unique bioactivity for inhibiting the anti-fungal, anti-tumor, and monoamine oxidase show promising applications in the pharmaceutical industry. It can be produced by the dehydrogenation of tetrahydroisoquinolines, however, the dehydrogenation products (e.g., isoquinolines) can be formed through this strategy. While the semi-dehydrogenation products, (e.g., dihydroisoquinolines) are more difficult to attain via a sustainable pathway. Hence, the electrolytic conversion of tetrahydroisoquinolines into dihydroisoquinolines at a low potential through the HWE system with a desired selectivity using low-cost nano-compounds will be economically interesting. Keeping this, Zhang's group proposed highly porous Ni2P nanosheet frameworks to selectively achieve value-added dihydroisoquinolines with high yields at the anode and boost H2 generation at the cathode. The in-situ induced Ni2+/Ni3+ redox active sites of the Ni2P electrode effectively adjusted the semi-dehydrogenation of tetrahydroisoquinolines to dihydroisoquinolines in 1.0 mol L–1 KOH/0.5 mmol L–1 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroisoquinoline electrolyte solution, revealing an onset potential of 1.48 V vs. RHE. The FE and selectivity of collected 3,4-dihydroisoquinoline products within the potential window of 1.35 to 1.45 V were measured to be 96% and 99%, respectively. The as-devised Ni2P∥Ni2P electrolyzer boosting electro-combined 1,2,3,4-tetrahydroiso-quinoline oxidation reaction/HER electrolysis displayed 300 mV reduction in cell potential as compared with that of the OWS at 20 mA cm−2. Moreover, the FE of released H2 and was found to be 100%. In terms of the anodic electrooxidation of amines coupled HER in HWE configuration, limited nano-structured materials have been presented. Considering the advantageous kinetics, narrow thermodynamic equilibrium voltages, wide-range resources in wastewater, and possible freed value-added products, extensive investigations underlining these topics are strikingly expected. 7 Conclusions As a green energy carrier, sustainable H2 gas has been regarded as a potential alternative to non-renewable fossil fuels. The huge energy crisis and environmental pollution concerns can be alleviated through the development of a sustainable and pure energy industry. Sustainable H2 production via water electrolysis represents an essential prerequisite H2 economy with zero toxic emissions. Fundamentally, H2 production via the HWE system includes the cathodic reduction of protons in an electrolytic reactor and subsequent interactions with various types of anodic electrooxidation reactions. As an innovative strategy, HWE reveals several unique advantages compared with the conventional OWS including smaller cell voltages, obscurity of explosive O2/H2 mixtures, and generation of value-added products. Due to the slow kinetics of anodic OER, H2 production via traditional OWS suffers from probable safety risks, poor investment returns, and large electric energy consumption. HWE systems involve the replacement of sluggish OER with thermodynamically favorable electrooxidation reactions for effective H2 production, thereby overcoming the weakness of conventional OWS. Herein, this review summarizes electro-coupled anodic oxidation reactions of small organic/biomass substrates with HER to construct energy-efficient synergistic electrolysis for obtaining high-purity H2 at the cathode with more valuable products at the anode. In comparison with the OER process, anodic electrooxidation reactions of small organic/biomass substrate molecules always reveal lower thermodynamic requirements, not only save energy for green H2 generation and abolish the crucial safety issue caused by membrane degradation and gas crossover but also bring in enormous economic and environmental advantages. We consequently provide a macroscopic understanding of HWE based on anodic electrooxidation reactions, rational engineering of electrode/electrocatalyst, and economic/environmental considerations. The synthetic strategies of novel electrodes/electrocatalysts, activity improvement, and structure-catalytic activity relationship were emphatically addressed. These strategies include electronic structure regulation, surface morphology optimization, defect engineering, and heterointerfacing. Morphological modification is mainly related to ion/mass transport within the pore architecture and active site exposure, which presents a universal pathway suitable for all types of catalytic processes. The remaining strategies are based on manipulating the electronic configuration, surface chemistry, electron transport rate, and binding between the reactants and electrocatalytic components. Bifunctional electrodes/electrocatalysts as the heart of the HWE system must be rationally engineered with the purpose of achieving high catalytic reactivity, desirable selectivity, and noticeable electrochemical stability performance. During the past few years, a potential number of nano-structured materials have been explored and applied to drive anodic electrooxidation reactions of small molecules. Specifically, non-precious Ni- and Co-based nanomaterials as more cost-effective electrodes/electrocata- lysts are admirable systems. We also discuss the recent research advances of precious and non-precious metal-based bifunctional electrodes/electrocatalysts for various anodic electrooxidation reactions and highlight their significant role in being integrated into the HWE system for sustainable low-voltage H2 production. Potential anodic substrates from organic/biomass feedstock with abundant reserves can be electro-coupled with HER to form value-added products, thus, supporting our society, realizing a generous cycle from waste to wealth with pure H2 generation, and eliminating ecological pollution by degrading them into toxic-free compounds simultaneously as presented in Fig. 3. Regardless of the great advances that have been made in the development of this field, it should be noticed that anodic electrooxidation reaction of small organic/biomass molecules synergizing HWE technology for energy-saving H2 production is still in the early stages of its progress even for the laboratory run, let alone for effective practical use. Some challenges still exist and there is a long road ahead for sustainable, cost-effective, and clean H2 production. 8 Challenges and future prospects To better regulate the laboratory efforts and realize commercialization of the HWE system, several foreseeable challenges and key problems must be taken into consideration. This may figure out some research topics for future investigations (Fig. 33 ). 8.1 Electrocatalyst To overcome sluggish kinetics triggered by complex electron transfer process during the above anodic electrooxidation reactions, novel non-noble transition metal-based nanomaterials (e.g., Ni, Co, Cu, Fe, Zn, Mn, Mo, V, etc.) have been extensively design and studied in HWE configurations, yielding breakthroughs on devising oxides, hydroxides, oxyhydroxides, alloys, MOFs, phosphides, sulfides, selenides, nitrides, selenides, and hybridization with carbon materials (Fig. 34 ). Some of them revealed comparable catalytic activities to those of benchmarking noble metal electrocatalysts. Enormous efforts have been devoted to tailor their physicochemical properties and morphological characteristics, thus achieving a high electrochemical performance. In this regard, combining with conducting supports, constructing hierarchical porous 3D architectures, and downsizing NPs can positively reinforce the utilization of active sites, boost ion/mass migration, and enlarge specific surface area. Alongside this, adjusting the physicochemical properties can be realized by increasing compositional complexity and modifying the electronic configuration. Multi-active phase hybridization, alloying, defect engineering, heterointerface construction, and surface functionalization, as well as heteroatomic doping synergically boost the reaction kinetics, accelerate the electron transportation rate, and modify the electronic structure. Despite we have witnessed, an intrinsic progress in the design of different nanomaterials for anodic electrooxidation reactions with promising catalytic activity, the potential of cost-effective transition metal-based nanomaterials is far from well explored as sustainable and tailorable electrodes/electrocatalysts for further applications. Hence, further advanced studies are still required to overcome challenges. (1) Despite many approaches that have been adopted to prepare efficient non-noble metal-based electrodes/electrocatalysts with suitable metal loading, the synthetic techniques are expensive and complicated, hence increasing the cost of final electrodes/electrocatalysts and making the yield and quality inadequate to fit the commercial and industrial requirements. The exploration of more gentle strategies that can manufacture proper metal loading electrodes/electrocatalysts on a large scale is necessary. (2) Stability is an important characteristic for evaluating the effectiveness of an electrode/electrocatalyst. Non-precious metal-based nanomaterials still suffer from stability issues, however, the stability tests are commonly carried out at lower current densities < 100 mA cm−2, which does not demonstrate stability and applicability in the industrial application (above 500 mA cm−2). Therefore, efforts should be diverted to boost the stability of electrodes/electrocatalysts to meet industrial requirements. (3) It is desirable to establish standardized measurements to compare and monitor various promising electrodes/electrocatalysts from different research teams. Screening the catalytic behaviors based on standardized conditions is beneficial for modulating the existing systems and identifying the viability of newly explored nanomaterials. Due to the difference in synthetic methodologies, different mass loadings, reaction conditions, and so on, it is difficult to accurately verdict the electrocatalytic performance of various nano-structured materials. Thus, aside from introducing more information on electrocatalytic performance such as normalized activity-based surface area and mass loading, overpotential, Tafel slope, durability, etc., in future works, it is strongly recommended to evaluate the electrochemical behavior under standard conditions to analyze and compare the activity of any new electrode/electrocatalyst. Furthermore, evaluating the optimized electrodes/electrocatalysts in an industrially relevant environment such as concentrated alkaline electrolytes > 6 mol L–1 KOH, relatively high temperature > 60 °C, and high current density > 200 mA cm−2 is encouraged. (4) Most of the presented electrodes/electrocatalysts for anodic electrooxidation reactions of organic/biomass substrates are usually active for catalyzing the OER process, leading to low selectivity for the targeted product at a high potential for most HWE systems. Therefore, understanding the difference between OER and anodic reactions of small molecules will manipulate the selectivity toward desired products. (5) Combining the experimental outcomes with the DFT calculations may elucidate reasonable mechanisms. However, most reported compounds contain multiple components where imperceptible variations during reaction are not fully expressed in DFT calculations. Consequently, more attention should be paid to assess nanomaterials with the support of advanced operando tools and theoretical analyses. Reports should be clarified to the atomic scale, considering the surface structure of metal centers, chemical bond polarity, crystal phase orientation, interface/heterojunction orientation/spacing, and other atomic-level characteristics with various effects (e.g., bifunctional effect, ensemble effect, strain effect, etc.). (6) Most precious metal-free active nano-compounds may experience a reconstruction step, in which high-valence metallic centers are formed and serve as true active sites. Unraveling the reaction mechanism represents an irreplaceable step for maximizing the overall efficiency of electro-integrating technologies. Thus, the electrochemical mechanisms of these active centers should be evaluated at multiscale levels with some advanced in-situ and ex-situ characterization tools such as in-situ electron spin resonance spectroscopy, in-situ TEM, in-situ XPS, in-situ Raman spectroscopy, in-situ diffuse reflectance FT-IR spectroscopy, in-situ synchrotron radiation instruments, etc. Alterations of architectures, compositions, and surface electronic configuration can be traced to understand the anode and cathode electrocatalytic coupling reactions mightily. (7) Up to now, most anodic electrooxidation reactions of organic/biomass molecules could perform well in alkaline conditions (e.g., 1.0 mol L–1 KOH, Tables 2–5), however, the HER process is kinetically more sluggish in these conditions. Consequently, synergistic electrolysis in low pH conditions may be a more energy-efficient approach. It is greatly desirable to obtain nano-structured electrodes/electrocatalysts that can drive synergistic electrolysis with high catalytic activity and selectivity as well as stability performance in acidic and/or neutral environments. 8.2 Electrolyzer Continuous optimization of organic/biomass electrooxidation synergizing HWE configuration should be evenly paramount from a laboratory to mass-scale manufacturing, yielding the maximum benefits of basic research to applied research. The development of new hybrid water electrolytic reactors still has lengthy a roadmap to go. (1) Considering the assessment of nano-tailored materials and electrolyte solutions with various concentrations of organic substrates, several electrocatalytic reaction factors were exercised when estimating the electrochemical activity, selectivity, and long-term durability performance. Hence, standardized test conditions/parameters of electrolyzers should be applied. Side-by-side, parameters like electrode spacing distance, analyte flow/feed dynamics, and reaction temperature should be controlled and the overall construction and maintenance costs shall be minimized. The rational construction of electrolyzer cell compartments not only optimizes the yield of targeted chemicals but functions in terms of separating the valuable species formed simultaneously at integrated electrodes. This requires professional cooperation between scientists and industrialists to further manipulate the electrocatalytic activity by identifying a particular emphasis on electrolyzer establishment and corresponding electrode compartment. (2) The systematic study under harsh conditions has rarely been reported. For a laboratory systematic evaluation, we encourage constructing practical alkaline electrolyzers with special arrangements to accomplish more benchmarking studies of promising cost-effective electrodes/electrocatalysts. (3) The energy cost of any integrated process also needs careful consideration. The controllable design and utilization of ingenious flow reactors/cells might become a suitable option for the practical application of electro-paired synergistic processes as it can boost mass transfer, decrease catalysis potentials, and enhance FE. The apparatus should contain a selectively permeable membrane to direct the immigration of ions and prevent the diffusion of reactants and reaction intermediates. A product harvesting unit and porous fluid capturing unit can be installed to control the access of liquid and accelerate the liberation of gas reactants from the whole system. The efficacious cooperation from all different disciplines to strengthen the advantages of interdisciplinary and push forward the research of synergistic electrocatalysis to produce green H2 and high-value-added species is highly desirable. (4) Furthermore, provincial issues may also be emphasized. The approachability of raw materials and renewable energy resources, commercial and industrial requirements, and climatic as well as geographical conditions change from one region to another region should be precisely considered. Hence, sophisticated electrolyzers must be developed for particular requirements. (5) Compared with the OWS, producing H2 gas via seawater electrolysis seems more cost-effective without additional desalination/purification proceedings. However, seawater electrolysis is seriously prohibited by anodic chloride evolution reaction, which competes with the OER process, creating unwanted species such as chlorine. As a result, the electrode/electrocatalyst, membranes, and other components will be harshly corroded by the accumulation of chlorine. More importantly, the electrooxidation reactions of organic molecules usually take place at a potential lower than those of chloride evolution reaction and even OER, thus, constructing electrolyzers-based synergistic electrolysis in hybrid seawater systems may increase the catalytic current density without interfering with the chloride evolution reaction and make the whole system more feasible for large-scale production of H2. (6) Refining and separation of anodic valuable species are very crucial for industrial applications. It is imperative to implement workable techniques to selectively capture targeted chemicals. Besides, recognizing novel molecules that can be electro-oxidized to hydrophobic rather than hydrophilic value-added products may be possible. At the same time, promoting the selectivity of ion-exchange membranes can prevent the crossover of small molecules in real practical use. 8.3 Choice of oxidizable substance Substances chosen for energy-saving and multi-functional synergistic electrolysis in the HWE configuration have a significant influence on electrolysis efficiency as well as targeted intermediates/products. (1) The usage of organic/biomass substrate molecules shall balance the reducibility, cost, and value of products. The solubility of organic molecules, competition with HER, value-added products, thermodynamics, and reaction pathway should be widely investigated for the proper selection of oxidation reactions. (2) The choice between full oxidation and partial oxidation represents a big issue in organic/biomass synergizing HWE technology. Full oxidation or electrochemical reforming can generate large H2 gas rates, meanwhile resulting in environmentally harmful and worthless CO2. On the one hand, partial oxidation supplies value-added species while sacrificing electrocatalytic behavior and reducing H2 production rates. Choosing between these two options must be comprehensively elaborated based on environmental impact, technological conditions, and industrial requirements. (3) Additionally, new potential alternative oxidation reactions should be applied for synergizing HWE technology to spread the versatility and reinforce the industrialization prospect of such a strategy. Now, there is a needful search for new electrooxidation reactions, such as biomass upgrading, barren plastic reforming, and abstraction of industrial organic pollutants. In general, efficient anodic electrooxidation of organic pollutants affords a pragmatic tactic to eliminate or even upgrade hazards. The electrolytic pairing of pollutant oxidation reaction and the HER will undoubtedly propose another sustainable pathway for producing useful chemicals and refining wastewater from industrial wastes. Given the advance, challenge, and opportunities in such a burgeoning scope, we notarize that this interesting technology is auspicious to rip off the limitations of traditional OWS and nominate an economic and sustainable section for green H2 production and simultaneous chemical upgrading. It is believed that through material nano-structuring advancement and efficient electrolyzer construction, such an appealing strategy will be utilized in practical chemical synthesis. This review may address some key guidelines for the discovery of efficient multi-functional HWE systems for energy-saving H2 and high-value-added co-generation and hopefully be more salutary for felicitous advances in future work. Acta, 2022, 403, 139700. Diab Khalafallah received his M.Sc. degree in 2012 and PhD degree in 2017. He is currently an Associate professor at the Faculty of Energy Engineering, Aswan University (Egypt). Khalafallah joined the Yancheng Institute of Technology (Jiangsu, China) as a researcher in the School of Materials Science and Engineering. His research activities are focused on developing functional materials for energy conversion and storage systems including hybrid water electrolysis, hydrogen evolution reaction, supercapacitors, and water splitting. Jong-Min Lee received his Ph.D. degree at the Department of Chemical Engineering, Columbia University. He worked in the Chemical Science Division, Lawrence Berkeley National Laboratory and at the Department of Chemical Engineering, University of California at Berkeley as a postdoctoral fellow. Currently, he is an associate professor in the School of Chemical and Biomedical Engineering at Nanyang Technological University. His research interests are electrochemistry, green chemistry, and nanotechnology. Dr. Qinfang Zhang is currently a full professor at the Yancheng Institute of Technology (Jiangsu, China). He received his PhD degree from the Nanjing University in 2005. His current research focus on the preparation and application of atomic clusters and oxyhalides. From 2005, he has published more than 100 research papers in peer-reviewed journals, such as: Phys. Rev. Lett., Nature Comm., Adv. Mater., Phys. Rev. B, Appl. Surf. Sci., Appl. Phys. Lett. His publications have been cited 3687 times, and his H-Index is 31. He has been leading 14 scientific research projects including the National Defense Science and Technology Innovation Special Zone Project, the National Natural Science Foundation of China, and the Provincial Outstanding Youth Fund and so on.

coredata.dc:description: Traditional overall water splitting has been regarded as a potential pathway for H2 production, but the intrinsic slow kinetics of the anodic oxygen evolution reaction severely hampers the efficiency of H2 production. Given the challenges in traditional water electrolysis, coupling the kinetically favorable anodic electrooxidation reactions of easily oxidizable substances with the hydrogen evolution reaction in a hybrid water electrolysis (HWE) configuration not only solves the pollutant emission and biomass recycling problems but also maximizes the return on energy profiteering. Various advanced compounds have been engineered through compositional regulation, structural optimization, surface nano-building, and electronic structure modification, yet some issues like tedious preparation and unsatisfactory durability still exist. Considering the gap between research and practical deployment, this review amply addresses the state-of-the-art achievements of synergistic electrocatalysis systems for the co-production of high-purity H2 and valuable products with a low energy consumption and high Faradaic efficiency. An overview of HWE system is presented first accompanied by a discussion on the design and engineering of high reactive/selective/stable electrodes/electrocatalysts for anodic oxidation of organic/biomass substrates. Importantly, the in-depth understanding of possible reaction mechanisms from both experimental and theoretical perspectives is elucidated to promote the efficiency of synergistic electrocatalysis. Subsequently, the recent research breakthroughs in the field of HWE technology are emphatically reviewed, providing a new room for low-voltage H2 generation from waste products and renewable feedstock. Some mechanism explorations, feasibility analyses, and correlation comparisons are highlighted. Finally, we propose the prospects on existing challenges with some opportunities for future research directions to push forward the progress in synergistic electrocatalysis configurations.
coredata.prism:publisher: Dalian Institute of Chemical Physics, the Chinese Academy of Sciences. Published by Elsevier B.V.
coredata.dc:title: Energy-saving electrochemical hydrogen production via co-generative strategies in hybrid water electrolysis: Recent advances and perspectives
